xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BRIEFLY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Shuttle setback NEW YORK, THURSDAY</p><p nitf:lede="true">America's hapless space program suffered another setback today when the shuttle Discovery's main engines failed a crucial launch pad test.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Joint test NEW YORK The US Department of Energy said today it will set off an underground nuclear blast on August 17 at its Nevada test site with Soviet scientists on hand to monitor it.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Fire under control BELGRADE Firefighters, soldiers and civilians were bringing under control today a forest fire which threatened the Yugoslav Adriatic resort of Sibenik.</p><p>Syrians injured BEIRUT An explosion ripped through a Syrian army checkpoint in Muslim West Beirut today, seriously wounding four Syrian soldiers, police and security sources said.</p><p> Elite unit formed MOSCOW The Afghan army formed an elite corps in March to defend Kabul, considered to be the "centre of the revolution," the Soviet army daily Red Star announced today.</p><p> Soldiers on rampage MOSCOW A Soviet newspaper said today that 82 elite paratroopers were arrested after a drunken rampage that followed a celebration of a military holiday.</p><p> Navy exercises SINGAPORE A British Navy aircraft carrier task group is to hold a series of exercises with the United States, Thailand, and Brunei over the next month.</p><p> Rust in hiding BONN Daredevil pilot Mathias Rust, released from a Soviet prison yesterday, will remain hidden from the media until his story appears in next Thursday's issue of Stern, the West German magazine announced.</p><p> $17 mil refund NEW YORK Rent-a-car company Hertz pleaded guilty today to overcharging customers for repairing damaged cars and agreed to make refunds of more than $A17 million and pay a fine of about $A8.5 million.</p><p> Jetty probe KUALA LUMPUR A royal commission will investigate the collapse of a jetty at a ferry crossing in Malaysia in which 31 people were killed and more than 800 injured.</p><p> Suharto picks 40 JAKARTAIndonesian President Suharto today named a new 40-member Supreme Advisory Council that includes former top civilian and military officials.</p><p> 6 soldiers killed COLOMBO Six Indian soldiers were killed by a Tamil rebel landmine in an eastern Sri Lanka village.</p><p> Threat to ozone NEW YORK Gaseous plumes from volcanoes might be contributing to depletion of the earth's protective ozone layer, scientists reported today.</p><p> Newspaper survey LONDON British newspapers which cannot even spell their own names correctly, others with dirty print and those which are the least up to date with news were revealed today in a Consumer's Association survey.</p><p> Nazi on trial BONN Former Nazi lieutenant-colonel Karl Hoecker, 76, goes on trial at Bielefeld on Monday accused of complicity in mass killings at the Maidanek concentration camp in Poland.</p><p> Rebels fall ADDIS ABABAEthiopia said today that the army had destroyed a rebel stronghold in the northern province of Tigray this week.</p><p> Babies' health NEW YORK The US, which ranks 19th in the world in saving the lives of its babies, should make health care for all infants and expectant mothers a national priority, a national commission said today.</p><p> Dundee on top NEW YORK Crocodile Dundee II has broken the US$100 million mark at the box office in North America, setting the movie on pace to beat its phenomenal predecessor.</p><p> And finally . . .</p><p> TAIPEI A survey of 10,000 chefs in Taiwan found that more than two-thirds were infected with athletes' foot, which flourished inside the sweaty galoshes they wore to stop themselves slipping on greasy floors, the government said yesterday.</p><p> HERALD BUREAU, REUTER, AFP, AAP, AP, PA</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">HERALDLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:44XM-F780-015G-S33P-00000-00<published>2002-01-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL-BIOG- ANDREW FRASER; Pg. 8</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Accusing MP burned down 2ha of state forest</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SIMON BENSON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE senior Coalition MP accusing fire authorities of negligence has burned down 2ha of state forest, The Daily Telegraph has learned.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Andrew Fraser, the Coalition's special adviser on rural affairs, last night admitted he had been careless and wished it had never happened.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It was an accident. I can understand why people might be upset," the National Party MP said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Seven rural fire brigade units and 25 volunteers were called to the incident late last year when Mr Fraser tried to burn off a paddock on his Coffs Harbour property.</p><p> The incident, which has angered senior fire authorities, comes after revelations that more than 20 per cent of fires in national parks are started on private property or other lands -- many from burn-offs.</p><p> Only 4 per cent of fires every year in NSW start in national parks.</p><p> An incident report, obtained by The Daily Telegraph, shows the fire on Mr Fraser's property escaped into the Lower Bucca State Forest, destroying 2ha.</p><p> "I blame the wind change," Mr Fraser said last night.</p><p> "I lit the fire in the morning against my normal better judgment … I had a meeting in the afternoon and I would normally do that sort of thing late in the day.</p><p> "It taught me a very valuable lesson.</p><p> "My carelessness was lighting the fire in the morning. I would love for it not to have happened. I would have loved to have not called the rural fire service out but these things happen."  But volunteer firefighters are outraged that Mr Fraser has accused them and the National Parks and Wildlife Service of not conducting enough hazard reduction to prevent the Christmas bushfire crisis.</p><p>Rural Fire Services Commissioner Phil Koperberg, when pressed for a comment last night said: "The incident has come to my attention in the past few days.</p><p> "Given the difficulties volunteers have to face on a daily basis, I am disappointed that someone who purports to be aware of the hazards, would allow a situation to develop where property was endangered and volunteers were called to suppress a fire."  The outspoken MP has led the charge of recent criticism of the Rural Fire Service chief Koperberg and the NPWS claiming it was "negligent" for not doing enough hazard reduction. He has also said the RFS should have done more as well.</p><p> Last night, a senior volunteer firefighter who attended the fire said it had been left unattended.</p><p> "[Mr Fraser] left the fire unattended and went in and got a cup of coffee," the senior officer said. "If there weren't full crews down there, it would have got off right through the State Forest.</p><p> "It could have been a lot worse … it was lucky that there was two brigades doing a hazard reduction burn nearby and we called them in for help.</p><p> "We threw everything we had at it."  Mr Fraser and his 15 year-old son started the burn-off, which he claimed he was required to do by law.</p><p> Mr Fraser said he asked his wife to make an emergency call to the Rural Fire Service when they realised it was out of control.</p><p> The incident was reported to the Rural Fire Service at Coffs Harbour at 11.04am on August 4, 2001.</p><p> The report concluded: "Owners burning off pile of logs/trees. Fire escaped into grassy paddock and some State Forest."  Fire units were called to the emergency from four brigades in the region.</p><p> They included Bucca, Coramba, Nana Glen and Moonee. The first units arrived at 11.17am and battled the blaze until 2.32pm.</p><p> Mr Fraser did not require a permit for the burn-off.</p><p> "It is our dry season and the wind was blowing from the northwest," said another volunteer who attended the fire.</p><p>Some poorly chosen  words of wisdom</p><p>Andrew Fraser, MP, commenting on the bushfires:</p><p>  * "The NPWS has been very negligent in their attitude towards hazard reduction burning."  2WS, January 4</p><p>  * "I would hope we don't get this collective statement that says hazard reduction is not the panacea."  2WS</p><p>  * "Let's hope [Rural Fire Service Commissioner] Phil Koperberg has a turnaround on hazard reduction burning in order that we don't have massive bushfires."  2WS</p><p>  * "One can only wonder … when a class action is taken against the government and NPWS for … negligence."  Press release January 3</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P8B-H3J0-TXN5-R13J-00000-00Coast on alert as winds fan flames to life2001-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 4Coast on alert as winds fan flames to lifeBUSHFIRES THE STATE ABLAZEEllen Connolly

Fires on the Central Coast flared late yesterday, jumping containment lines and travelling towards houses at Peats Ridge and Mangrove Mountain.

With fire fuelled by easterly winds, firefighters were racing to stop one reaching rough and inaccessible terrain at Spencer and the Dharung National Park.

"There are no properties under threat at this stage but we know from the 1994 bushfires how quickly the fire can move through the area," said Superintendent Arthur Owens, of the Gosford Rural Fire Service.

He said the main priority at Peats Ridge, Mangrove Mountain and Central Mangrove was to protect lives and property.

Fires in the state's north and Central West and in the ACT were brought under control yesterday afternoon.

A fire service spokesman said the blazes were still burning as far north as Yamba and south to Shoalhaven.

"They're under close watch in case they reignite," he said.

Earlier, Wollongong residents battled fires at Kembla Heights and Windy Gully, but they were saved by a change in wind direction. About 300 residents remained on standby for evacuation last night.

The Bulli Rural Fire Service superintendent, Dominic Lane, said the fire had travelled more than 20 kilometres and was less than 10km from Windy Gully and Kembla Heights.

Fire crews were backburning on the western side of Mt Kembla in an attempt to contain the blaze and stop it spreading to the town.

A second fire was burning on the steep escarpment north of Wollongong, around Helensburgh, after the evacuation of 1600 residents on Christmas Day.

Residents were allowed back into the area to collect pets and possessions and also to clean out fridges and put out rubbish.

Department of Agriculture inspectors also entered the area to inspect a nature reserve where horses are kept but found no injured animals.

In Canberra, four major bushfires claimed 1500 hectares of land in three days.

Large areas of pine forest in the Stromlo area were destroyed, although no homes were lost.

The ACT Emergency Services Minister, Ted Quinlan, said he was amazed at the damage he had seen on an aerial tour of the affected area and praised the efforts of firefighters for saving property.

"The fires came very close to homes and the fact that no homes were lost is a testament to the hard work of all parties involved in this enormous task," he said.

"These people abandoned Christmas dinners and family celebrations to protect our city, and for that I thank them."

In the Central West, at Gilgandra, a forest fire that had been burning for three days was finally contained, as was a blaze in a state forest at Yeoval, 60km south of Dubbo.

Inspector Steve Bent, from Narromine police, said many emergency workers from the area had been deployed to Sydney, where the situation was far worse.

"Everything's contained here, really. Most of our people have gone down to Sydney," Inspector Bent said.

Fires in the Mudgee area were brought under control and roads, which had been closed due to falling trees, were reopened.

In the Wyong area, firefighters were kept busy extinguishing spot fires in Maddens Plains.

MAJOR FIRES ACROSS NSW

* Narromine/Cabonne 32,680 hectares burnt. Fires have eased but there is still some activity along Burrabadine.

* Wollongong/Wingecarribee 39,000ha burnt, including in the Bourke River area. Fires still close to residential areas. Ten houses have been lost.

* Mudgee All fires now contained and controlled.

* Shoalhaven Properties still at risk at Falls Creek, St Georges Basin and Wandandian. About 40 homes destroyed.

* Cessnock Crews trying to contain a 140ha fire.

* Richmond Valley/Maclean Two fires being controlled.

* Kempsey Phillip Drive fire has been contained but the Byrne Plantation fire has not. No threat to property at the moment.

* Oberon/Mulwaree Lockmaree fire (1600ha) not contained, potential to expand into the Blue Mountains National Park.

* Hawkesbury Two fires yet to be contained. Life and property is under threat in the Graham Creek area. 14 houses destroyed at Blaxland Ridge.

* Wollondilly/Campbelltown Appin Road and Holsworthy fires have combined, presenting a small risk to properties. About 40 houses lost, as well as shops and factories.

* Gosford Fire currently controlled, but still potential threat to property.

* Singleton/Muswellbrook Wattle Creek fire is outside containment lines but no property under threat.

* Grafton/ Pristine Waters Property lost and fires are not yet contained.

urn:contentItem:4P6W-1G50-TXN5-R33X-00000-00YOUR WEEK AHEAD2004-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 43YOUR WEEK AHEADWITH LILITH

Marcel Proust understood the real voyage of discovery lies not in seeking new lands, but in seeing with new eyes. This weekend kickstarts the astrological year with the sun, Mercury and new moon in Aries, sign of new beginnings, coinciding with the equinox, Mayan new year and massive worldwide peace rallies. If you feel peace is important, spend some time joining your thoughts with most of the other humans on the planet and never underestimate your ability to make a difference.

Pisces Feb 20 Mar 20

Be warned: this week is labelled "handle with care". Emotions are volatile, escalating from mere differences of opinion to nuclear holocaust in nanoseconds. But keep to reasonably peaceful surroundings, and socialising Pisceans could enjoy a raucous, out-there time.

Aries Mar 21 Apr 20

Happy birthday, Rams. As this week's Sun turns your fleece gold, you energetic chili peppers are wickedly witty and positively smoking. You'll know exactly what you want and shouldn't have any problem getting it. But Mars in Taurus is the transit of bossyboots, so try not to leave scorch marks on others as you pass.

Taurus Apr 21 May 21

You finally decided to do something new? This week you get your chance. To approach things a different way? Now's the hour. Take a walk on the wild side? It's time. Listen to what your feelings are telling you and get ruthlessly honest about what you really want because several versions of it are heading your way.

Gemini May 22 - Jun 21

With so much random energy flying round, this week could be either twice as exciting as usual, or double the trouble. Being a Gemini you can expect both. Its forward motion brings sweet relief from the suspended animation of playing the waiting game, but that doesn't mean everything's sorted. It's not, by a long shot.

Cancer Jun 22 Jul 23

Aries transits can feel like the armies of Genghis Khan advancing on your crab toes, sending you skittering in a frenzied jitterbug for the safety of Curmudgeon Castle. But this week also lights your fire, so the absolutely fabulous new you can make its entrance with a few tentative steps.

Leo Jul 24 Aug 23

Overcommitted? Underassisted? So much going on in Lionland you could easily blow a fuse? Don't shoot the messenger. You need to know it is slaves' annual month off, so laying down the law will fall on deaf ears. But, hey, just be your charming self and you'll get all the help you need.

Virgo Aug 24 Sep 23

This week's wilful citizens won't play by the rules although they will operate according to their own nonconformist code, ignoring advice, small print and details. It's a disgracefully near-enough's-good-enough world this week, Virgos, utterly lacking in finesse. Call up your favourite Libran for a therapeutic whinge session.

Libra Sep 24 Oct 23

This happy-go-lucky week heads straight for the bottom line. So while you're working on a stylish new crawl, you'll be glad to know Arian transits actually help Librans make decisions quickly. Doesn't that just tickle your fancy? Or not? Or what?

Scorpio Oct 24 Nov 22

Ooh la la! There's a fire in your heart and we're talking serious heat here. You know you can use your Scorpionic energy to heal or hurt. Resist any temptation for payback, which will only pay you back. Consider taking Vajrayogini, the Tibetan Buddhist goddess who transmutes all passions into compassion, as this week's role model.

Sagittarius Nov 23 Dec 21

The flammable Ram can amp up the impulsive side of Sagittarians, but you'd be unwise to rush into anything this week. Don't get pressured into foolhardy moves or self-sabotaging behaviour. Take the time to think things through before doing, or saying, anything you may regret.

Capricorn Dec 22 Jan 20

This week brings a mixed bag of blessings for Capricorns and their loved ones. The good news is that Martian vibes motivate you. The not-so-fabulous part is this annual do-it-my-way transit also magnifies that uniquely Capricornian belief that you alone know what's best for everyone else. It so isn't true.

Aquarius Jan 21 Feb 19

Snap, crackle, pop! Is that a forest fire or your brainboxes sizzling in synaptic frenzy? Aries transits spark wild and wonderful ideas, outrageous behaviour and transcendental changes divine madness, in fact. This challenging, full-forward transit can frighten the faint-hearted, but you like changes which is good because you're about to get plenty.

urn:contentItem:4436-8NH0-015G-T3PN-00000-00<published>2001-09-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WEEKEND; Pg. W17</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Whisper of Evans</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SHAUNAGH O'CONNOR</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SHAUNAGH O'CONNOR meets the man whose whisper found millions of listeners.</p><p nitf:lede="true">NICHOLAS Evans admits he goes to bed with all his readers.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Thank goodness the author is not speaking literally -- he may well have the energy for a small readership, but being a bestselling writer means he now has millions of readers around the world.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "You go to bed with these people, they take your book to bed with them and put it on their night stand," he says.</p><p>"And you share this quiet time, just the two of you, and that's a wonderful thing."</p><p> Evans is best known for his first work, The Horse Whisperer, which was made into a movie starring Robert Redford and Kristin Scott Thomas.</p><p> That book was the first time Evans exhibited what was to become his trademark: taking strange-but-true, intriguing occupations and turning them into blockbuster stories.</p><p> The Horse Whisperer was about American horse trainers from what was once the wild west who can "speak" to their charges, communicating in "horse language".</p><p> Evans' new book, The Smoke Jumper, takes a special breed of firefighter, those who are airlifted into fires to save those trapped inside infernos.</p><p> Evans' books generally mix romance with rugged heroes and adventure tales and The Smoke Jumper is no exception.</p><p> Jumpers Ed Tully and Connor Ford are best friends, both in love with Julia, who must choose between the two men.</p><p> Connor is also a photographer who travels through war-torn Africa to capture images of disaster and despair.</p><p> And no one could accuse Evans of choosing material that lets him sit back and relax.</p><p> He sets himself huge research tasks each time he writes a novel.</p><p> "That stems from a journalistic background, in the sense that that was my first job," Evans says.</p><p> "Real life is just so rich and the process of research is crucial to me.</p><p> "If you're going to make a character who's a smoke jumper you need to know what you're talking about.</p><p> "As a reader you have no experience of these areas I'm writing about and accept it as plausible, but the people involved in that area should see it as real, too.</p><p> "If somebody working with horses saw that I had done something completely wrong in The Horse Whisperer, it would really bug me, so I just want to get it right."</p><p> The man who sets his stories in the American west is, in fact, a mild-mannered English gent who lives on an idyllic Devon property through which the River Dart runs through into a wooded glade.</p><p> He lives with partner Charlotte and dog Hopi, "the second love of my life".</p><p> Evans came to writing novels after studying law, working as a newspaper journalist and then making TV documentaries and movies.</p><p> He came across the notion of smoke jumpers at the same time he was thinking about major life choices.</p><p> His 25-year marriage was coming to an end and he thought fire was a great metaphor for purging, clearing and starting again.</p><p> And jumping into the flames of a forest fire seemed a great metaphor for leaping into what life has to offer.</p><p> He wanted to describe that moment in our lives when we have to choose between either the decent thing -- "the honour or the loyalty or things we're brought up thinking are the things we should stay with" -- or ambition.</p><p> "And whether you have the guts to jump into the flames to go and get it," the author says.</p><p>EVANS knows people wonder what a Brit is doing writing about the American west, but explains the west is his subject matter because "I was an Indian for the first 10 years of my life".</p><p> Playing cowboys and Indians was a favourite hobby when he was young, with just an older sister for company.</p><p> "If you're a boy and you have an older sister they're like a generation apart, they're so sophisticated," Evans says.</p><p> "You want to play with them, but they don't want to play with you."</p><p>Nicholas Evans is guest speaker at the next Herald Sun/Collins Booksellers literary lunch on Tuesday, October 16. The two-course lunch begins at noon at the Hotel Sofitel, Collins St. Ph: 9653 7744.</p><p>THE SMOKE JUMPER</p><p>by Nicholas Evans, Bantam Press, rrp $45</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49KH-5JD0-01S8-84GT-00000-00<published>1988-01-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Arson feared in Hills park blaze</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>TOM MENZIES; PETER HAYNES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The first major Adelaide Hills bushfire this summer, which destroyed about five hectares of bushland at the Morialta Conservation Park yesterday, probably was deliberately lit.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Police and Country Fire Services authorities believe the fire was lit in roadside grass about halfway along a two-kilometre road which runs from the park entrance to its kiosk.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> As temperatures throughout the State climbed into the 40s, two other major fires flared, one in the South-East and another in the Mid-North.</p><p>Firefighters last night controlled a fire in the Myora Forest, 20 kilometres north-east of Mount Gambier.</p><p> The CFS reported 17 fires in SA yesterday, most of them minor.</p><p> In the Morialta park late last night, about 10 CFS units were mopping up hot spots of the blaze which was expected to be completely extinguished by this morning.</p><p> The fire was first sighted from the Mount Lofty spotter tower at 4 p.m. and within about 30 minutes both CFS spotter-bomber planes, the Westpac State rescue helicopter, 12 CFS fire units and eight National Parks and Wildlife Service units were fighting the blaze which at times sent flames soaring up to 50 metres.</p><p> Twelve other CFS units and the Metropolitan Fire Service were on standby.</p><p> The De Havilland Beaver planes made continuous water-bombing runs while CFS officers in the helicopter relayed information about the fire.</p><p> Roads around the park - Norton Summit, Old Norton Summit, and Morialta Falls roads - were sealed off by police and only residents were permitted to enter the area.</p><p> Electricity to thousands of houses from Para Hills to Magill faltered momentarily when the fire engulfed 275,000-volt power lines connecting substations between the two suburbs. The heat caused a short-circuit across the lines.</p><p> An ETSA spokesman said last night linesmen were examining the lines to ensure no damage had occurred.</p><p>CFS assistant chief operations officer Mr Howard McBeth said the fire had not threatened any houses.</p><p>NPWS ranger Mr Jim Earl said the fire had caused very little environmental damage because of the unwanted proliferation of wild olive trees in the area.</p><p> In the South-East, the Myora Forest fire swept through more than 20 hectares of pine forest before being contained.</p><p> The fire was reported to be "still out of control" at 7.45 p.m., but the CFS said light winds from the south-west steered it out of the forest towards grasslands where it was easier to control. Between 20 and 30 SA forestry and CFS units, assisted by Victorian firefighters, worked in "near-century heat" and unusually low humidity to battle the blaze.</p><p> The fire, a few kilometres from the Victorian border, was in a plantation owned by SA Perpetual Forests Ltd and was said to have burnt pine trees for a distance of about three kilometres.</p><p> No houses were near its path.</p><p> A Woods and Forests Department spokesman said the fire cause was not known but was likely to be "human".</p><p> In the Mid North, a fire late last night was burning out of control in inaccessible bush country near Mount Remarkable, 3.5 kilometres north-west of Melrose.</p><p> The CFS said the fire was started by lightning and was believed to have destroyed about 10 hectares.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>2 photos: jim earl gets a hose-down and a drink; morialtaconservation park bushfire; National Parks and Wildlife Service officer Jim Earl takesa break from fighting the Morialta bushfire to get ahose-down and a drink. Smoke billowing from the MorialtaConservation Park blaze yesterday afternoon.; Brodie, Campbell</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P84-VCM0-TXN5-R32S-00000-00SHORT CUTS1998-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisTELEVISIONPg. 12SHORT CUTSRACHEL BROWNE

What I Watch

Do you have much time to watch TV?

I don't watch very much because I'm either working on the show or catching up on my school work or reading scripts for films. I have sort of strange tastes. I don't watch sitcoms. I really only watch ESPN, the sports channel. Sometimes I'll watch the History Channel, PBS (America's public broadcaster) and the Travel Channel.

So, do have any favourite shows?

I'm not big on TV. I don't really have any favourite shows. I tend to watch it only late at night if I have a little time before bed. It puts me to sleep. I'll watch 45 minutes and then nod off. I don't even have a TV in my bedroom.

What about movies?

I like going to the movies but I'd rather wait and get a tape of it later and watch it at my house. I don't like going to the big theatres, except for something like Titanic, which you need to see on a bigger screen. The theatres here are always so crowded. The majority of the people don't watch the film, they're talking or throwing popcorn at each other. I just can't concentrate in that environment.

NOW & THEN HEELERS AGE WELL

AUSTRALIA's most popular drama, Blue Heelers, reaches the 200-episode milestone this week. Set in a small country town with the action focusing on a cop shop staffed by young, dedicated officers under the watchful eye of the fair but fearless Sergeant Tom Croydon, Blue Heelers premiered on Channel 7 in January, 1994.

But for five years before its debut, the series was a twinkle in the eye of co-creator Hal McElroy who was inspired by a friend's 18-year-old son. The lad had just graduated from the Police Academy and was preparing to enter the workforce; gun, handcuffs and notebook the tools of his trade.

The boy's age got McElroy thinking. He learnt that 60 per cent of the police force was younger than 26 and the figure was increasing.

Young people becoming cops, thought McElroy, would make good drama. He teamed with scriptwriter Tony Morphett and five years and many re-writes later the series went to air with a cast of known stars - John Wood, Julie Nihill and Martin Sacks - and newcomers Lisa McCune, William McInnes and Grant Bowler.

Two hundred episodes later, the series has lost Bowler (killed off in 1996) and gained Damian Walshe-Howling as Constable Adam Cooper, Tasma Walton as Constable Deidre "Dash" McKinley and, the most recent addition, Paul Bishop.

It has also gained considerably in the ratings. In 1994, it drew an average of 393,700 viewers in Sydney. By 1995, this had increased to 546,000, then to 692,000 in 1996 and 732,000 in 1997.

Blue Heelers might be set in the bush but that hasn't limited its scope to stories about cattle rustling. It has covered everything from sex crimes to suicide, drug addiction and AIDS.

But perhaps the most enduring storyline is Maggie Doyle (McCune) and P J Hasham's (Sacks) off-on romance. The consummation of their relationship in a collapsed mine shaft in an episode screened last year was one of the program's highest-rating moments. But will viewers have to wait another 200 episodes before the canoodling coppers walk down the aisle?

OFF THE AIR

"Everyone is alone. It's just easier to take in a relationship."

Ally McBeal's grim view on modern love, Ally McBeal.

"I've often thought the only thing missing from 60 Minutes was the laugh track."

Paul McDermott, who probably won't replace Charles Wooley, Good News Weekend.

"Your face looks like somebody tried to put out a forest fire with a screwdriver."

Phillips knows how to make Ugly Bob feel happier about his physical appearance, South Park.

TWO ILLUS: ENDURING: With 200 episodes in handcuffs, the cast of Blue Heelers is looking forward to more arresting drama in the bush.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YK60-TXN5-R2S4-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1987-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 15REGULAR SHORTS

SPYCATCHER NO 1 SELLER

NEW YORK, Monday: Spycatcher, the book written by former British intelligence officer Peter Wright and banned for security reasons by the British Government, hit the top of The New York Times best seller list published here yesterday. The autobiography, which the British Government attempted to prevent from being published in the United States, was released in the country last month. - AFP

DOG HALTS TRAFFIC

TEL AVIV, Monday: A german shepherd snarled traffic on one of this city's busiest streets around midnight today when it refused to leave its master who had passed out drunk on the pavement. Witnesses said the dog bit three people who approached the pair, as a traffic jam mounted on Tel Aviv's Dizengoff Street. The dog was eventually taken to the pound. Its master dried out in another enclosure. - AFP

TOURIST FIGHTS ALLIGATOR

NEW YORK, Monday: A British tourist who fought off an alligator which attacked him while he was water skiing in Daytona, Florida, escaped with minor injuries to his right foot, authorities said. John Sienesi of Cranbrook, England, was floating in his life jacket as he struggled at the weekend with the bull alligator, estimated to be two metres to 2.5 metres long. He said he felt something grab his ankle. "I could feel teeth. There was a lot of pressure, I could feel him pulling me right down. It was pretty weird." Police said the bouyancy helped prevent him from being pulled under. - AP

MARCH IN NAGASAKI

TOKYO, Monday: About 5,000 people marched in Nagasaki yesterday to call for the abolishment of atomic weapons like the one that devastated their city 42 years ago. - AP

FLOODS KILL 223 IN INDIA

NEW DELHI, Monday: Monsoon floods have killed at least 223 people and left thousands homeless, damaged crops and killed livestock, in eastern and north-eastern India, the Press Trust of India (PTI) said today. Floods sweeping down the Brahmaputra River cut off road links between Assam and neighbouring Nagaland and Manipur States in the northeast today. - AFP

HUMAN NATURE BLAMED

BEIJING, Monday: China's most serious forest fire in memory, which killed 193 people, was due to an unusually long dry spell and human mismanagement, a study by more than 100 scientists has found. The New China News Agency quoted the study as saying that those managing the forest in the Daxinganling area ignored warnings of the fire dangers, including one the day before the fire began, and failed to take adequate precautions. Two forestry officials were sacked in June for poor management of the fire. - Reuter

SECOND SEPTUPLET DIES

LONDON, Monday: A second of Britain's first septuplets died early today. The baby who died was a girl named Leah, the sixth of the babies to be born. The septuplets were born three months prematurely to 27-year-old Mrs Susan Halton and her husband, Neil, on Saturday. One of the babies - a boy - died after just 25 minutes. The survival chances of the remaining five babies are rated at less than 50 per cent. - PA

ELECTION BLOW FOR WINGTI

PORT MORESBY, Monday: The Prime Minister, Mr Paias Wingti's parliamentary majority has been reduced to two seats by an Opposition victory in a by-election. The millionaire businessman, Mr Paul Pora, dealt Mr Wingti a double blow by winning the Prime Minister's former seat of Hagen Open for the National Party, part of Mr Michael Somare's Pangu-led Opposition alliance. - AAP

urn:contentItem:49K3-7M00-01S8-D1FK-00000-00<published>1987-08-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BRIEFLY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Heatwave tipped ATHENS, WEDNESDAY Another heatwave is expected to hit Greece within two days.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Forecasters today warned that temperatures would climb back into the 40s on Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A heatwave which ended on July 29 claimed 900 lives.</p><p>Rebels strike MANILA Communist rebels today killed the deputy mayor of a town north of Manila, and troops in the capital fired on Leftist strikers, injuring 13 people.</p><p> 'No doubt' on Ivan JERUSALEM An Israeli prosecutor, ending a six-day cross-examination of alleged Nazi war criminal John Demjanjuk, today accused him of lying and said there was no doubt he was the Treblinka death camp guard known as "Ivan the Terrible".</p><p> Pilots grounded LONDON Twenty Rumanian pilots who have flown thousands of Britons to holidays in Europe this summer have been grounded after four of them failed British competence tests, transport officials said today.</p><p>Jordan jet deal LONDON Jordan is negotiating with the Soviet Union to buy advanced MiG-29 fighters after being refused permission to buy US-built F-16s and F-20s, Jane's Defence Weekly magazine said today.</p><p> Good egg BONN A green egg with a cholesterol content eight times lower than normal is to be put on the market soon.</p><p> A breeder from Bavaria produced the egg from a cross between the Andean black Araucana species and an Asian wild chicken.</p><p> Space station MOSCOW Moscow will soon launch a cosmic ray research station designed to help scientists study this galaxy and others, a Soviet scientist said today.</p><p> Matterhorn ban GENEVA For the first time in many years, Zermatt's 55 professional mountain guides are refusing to take clients up the famed Matterhorn because of unseasonably harsh weather which has caused a numbers of deaths.</p><p> Tenor ill MADRID Spanish tenor Jose Carreras, 41, is likely to be flown to the US within a few days in the medical battle to combat a serious blood disorder.</p><p> Confidence vote ROME Italy's 47th government since World War 2 won a parliamentary vote of confidence tonight but the fragile five-party coalition is expected to last less than a year.</p><p> Lennon tape sale LONDON A 1968 tape recording in which the late John Lennon discussed his lifestyle and philosophy sold for 23,650 pounds ($A53,616) at a Sotheby's auction today.</p><p> The Hard Rock Cafe in New York bought the tape.</p><p> Spy book fine LONDON Street trader Ian Wills, who was arrested after dressing up as Uncle Sam to sell copies of the banned book Spycatcher, was fined 50 pounds ($A113.36) today.</p><p>French fire MARSEILLE Hundreds of firemen were fighting a forest fire which broke out in south-eastern France today. It has destroyed 150 hectares of forest and scrub in the Var region and injured five people.</p><p> Karami case STOCKHOLM A Lebanese soldier, 25, arrested on suspicion of assassinating Lebanese Prime Minister Rashid Karami, was remanded in custody by a Swedish court today pending further investigations.</p><p> Caledonia call TOKYO Japan has called on France to hold talks with indigenous Melanesians and the South Pacific Forum on settling New Caledonia's political future, Foreign Ministry sources said today.</p><p> And finally . . .</p><p> LONDON One of Britain's oldest women, Mrs Charlotte Hughes, 110, flew into the Guinness Book of Records yesterday.</p><p> She crossed the Atantic in Concorde, the oldest woman to have taken an unscheduled flight and certainly the oldest to have flown the Atlantic.</p><p> "I feel as if I am the Queen Mother," said Mrs Hughes.</p><p> TONY WILSON, DAILY TELEGRAPH, REUTER, AP</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">HERALDLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-1CM0-TXN5-R2W0-00000-00Cole sore2003-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisMETROPg. 23Cole soreMUSICSACHA MOLITORISZ

LLOYD COLE

Where Footbridge Theatre, Holme Building, University of Sydney, Parramatta Road, Glebe

When December 12 (sold out) and 13, doors open 7.30pm

How much $46

Bookings 9266 4800

The master of melancholic pop is pissed off as usual. SACHA MOLITORISZ finds out why.

After making distinctive, beautiful pop music for two decades, Lloyd Cole has come to realise one thing: he has an issue with Sydney muso Brendan Gallagher.

"What's disappointing about this Australian tour is that normally I play two sets," says Cole. "I've been spending the first hour playing songs from my new record and the quieter songs from my old records. Then, after a break, I play my more well-known songs.

"But on this trip I'm not allowed to play two sets because I have to have an Australian support act. I suggested we could make a donation to the musician's union for the same amount, but apparently I'm not famous enough to get around that rule, like Lou Reed and Neil Diamond were. So I'll have about

half-an-hour less to play."

OK, so Cole has no specific beef with Gallagher - he'd simply rather not have to share the stage with anyone in Sydney next week.

To be fair, the Englishman does have an embarrassment of tunes to work through.

In 1984, aged 23, he and his band the Commotions made a memorable debut with the album Rattlesnakes. In an era of pirate shirts and pretense, songs such as Perfect Skin and Forest Fire stood out like ... well, like good songs.

In a poll the next year, NME named it among its top 100 albums of all time.

Cole and the Commotions released two more excellent albums, Easy Pieces (1985) and Mainstream (1987), before he moved to New York. In 1990, with Matthew Sweet on bass, Cole released a self-titled solo debut.

After two edgier albums and the more quiet, reflective Love Story, Cole cut a couple of albums with a new band, the Negatives.

He also started to perform live with just an acoustic guitar and a microphone.

"Over the past four or five years, I've been doing that almost exclusively," he says.

"My new album grew out of that."

That album is Music in a Foreign Language, which is even more gentle than Love Story. That said, Cole is patently mining the same vein of erudite, Leonard Cohen-style lyrics and catchy, acoustic-based melodies as ever. At 42, Cole's preoccupations and tastes have clearly remained essentially unchanged - even if he does describe this record as a risk.

"I did feel I was being slightly bold in making a record that is so removed from rock and youth culture," he says. "On this one, you've got no snare drum. That means you can't call it rock'n'roll. There's a lack of irony, and a level of simplicity and bleakness, that was a little frightening."

A year ago, he spent five months of "near complete solitude" recording the album in western Massachusetts, where he lives.

It couldn't have been more DIY: Cole played piano and guitar before knocking out the lead vocals in about a day. Only at the end did Cole recruit friends - including Commotion Neil Clark on guitar - to record additional parts.

Cole says he was more worried about feel than precision. "I did my own engineering and I was never too worried about being perfectly in tune," he says. "Bob Dylan's Highway 61 [Revisited] is probably my favourite record, and that's perfectly out of tune and out of time.

"Even back when we were making records with the Commotions, we tried to have an element of feel. Not that it's easy to do when you're young, white Caucasians. It's no accident that Keith Richards was always out of it."

In mood, the end result is not unlike Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds's The Boatman's Call: unadorned, lilting, sad - if less dark. Fittingly, Music in a Foreign Language contains a cover of that album's People Ain't No Good.

"I'd just been singing it in my live show for 2 1/2 years. And when songs are that good, you don't have to do much."

Apart from playing People Ain't No Good, how does Lloyd decide what to perform live?

"I don't play Perfect Skin very often because it's not very good in this format," he says. "That's the only thing that vetoes a song.

"It's amusing to find that songs you thought weren't that strong, when you break them down, you find they are quite strong. And others you thought were good, you find they were just smoke and mirrors all along."

ILLUS: Lloyd Cole has the classic profile of a Greek god. OK, perhaps that's over the top.

urn:contentItem:44DX-HCJ0-015H-91YS-00000-00<published>2001-07-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WEEKEND; Pg. 44</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Kookaburras have last laugh</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DON KNOWLER</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE early morning laughter of the kookaburra has been missing from our valley these winter months.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> During the spring and summer the laughter acts like an alarm clock as streaks of golden sunlight pierce the strands of gum and wattle at the end of my garden. But as the log fires of winter flooded the valley with smoky haze at the start of autumn the kookaburras retreated.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> I'm sure it has nothing to do with the fires, although I've seen other species, such as tawny frogmouths, looking a little nervous when smoke invades their territory, fearing a forest fire might be heading their way.</p><p>There are still plenty of kookaburras about in Hobart, and in the last week I've heard their laughter ringing out from the roof of the Collegiate School in Davey St, where a pair enjoys sparring with forest ravens.</p><p> Seeing kookaburras at the Waterworks Reserve last week, I reasoned they might be my birds, but it still didn't answer the question why they had deserted my garden.</p><p> Last week, moving a pile of logs from the side of the house that was catching too much rain, I found the answer.</p><p> Hiding in the wood, snug against the winter winds blowing off Mount Wellington, must have been virtually my entire garden's population of metallic skinks.</p><p> Since I moved into this valley a year ago, I've been concentrating on our garden birds, and I must admit I had not given the skinks a second glance, although I had seen them scurrying about the garden all summer.</p><p> I didn't even know their name, just calling them garden lizards as we would in Britain, and it was only when I consulted a few books on reptiles in the library that I discovered their true identity.</p><p> The name metallic skink suits them well, for when I held one in my hand it had a bronzy sheen to its soft-brown skin, and a dark stripe running down the sides of its body.</p><p> In summer, the kookaburras perch on a young stringy-bark in a neighbour's garden, with their heads pointed downwards, as though their gigantic beaks were too heavy for them.</p><p> But I now know the kookaburras are looking for the skinks, because they occasionally flick up their heads towards my overgrown rock garden on the other side of the fence, before flying into the shrubbery to stab at food in the undergrowth.</p><p> I've never been able to establish what they were catching -- I thought it was insects -- but it can only be the skinks because they are so common in that location.</p><p> Although I enjoy the kookaburras in the garden, the joy of seeing them is always tinged with a little sadness that they do not really belong in Tasmania, and they must be having an adverse impact on the local environment.</p><p> The kookaburras, originally only found on the mainland, were introduced to Tasmania last century.</p><p> One theory says they were introduced at the time of federation, because the fathers of our new nation wanted all of Australia's "icons", which distinguished the continent from other parts of the British Empire, to be found in every Australian state.</p><p> In a year when Australia celebrates the centenary of federation, it's worth considering that from an environmental point of view there is much that has happened in the past 100 years that we cannot be proud of.</p><p> The misguided decision to introduce kookaburras to Tasmania has had a detrimental impact on native creatures here, particularly lizards, skinks, snakes and frogs.</p><p> The lesson here is that it is not just creatures and plants imported from overseas that are a pest. Australian species not native to a specific area can have the same impact as a fox or feral cat.</p><p> I can't bring myself to describe our kookies as pests, but I'm sure the skinks would have a say on the subject.</p><p> When I moved the logs the semi-hibernating skinks slowly made their way to a high wall holding our laundry line, and into the drying washing itself.</p><p> One found its way into the pocket of my jeans and a few days later it dropped out onto a table in one of Hobart's smarter restaurants as I pulled out my wallet to pay the bill.</p><p> The kookaburras would have had a good laugh at that.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4B46-HHX0-01S8-D2FK-00000-00<published>1993-11-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BELANGLO LINK TO PRISONER</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>OWENS W</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>POLICE are expected to interview a Queensland man, suspected of committing the Belanglo backpacker murders.</p><p> The man, in his mid-20s, has prior convictions for sexual offences and is serving a 12-year term in a Brisbane jail for armed robbery and assault.</p><p> He is believed to have admitted, during a videotaped interview, that he owned a Ruger rifle (the make involved in the murders) and had a good knowledge of the area where the bodies of the murder victims were found.</p><p> When asked if it was safe for backpackers to hitch-hike, the suspect - who maintains he is innocent and whom NSW police said was only one of hundreds of suspects - is believed to have replied: "Yes, unless they encounter someone like me." A reliable source said the prisoner had been a prime suspect for some time and was under observation in the jail by undercover police.</p><p> He is in a cell by himself and no moves have been made to charge him.</p><p> NSW police are continuing their investigations and the search for more bodies.</p><p> The suspect was recently interviewed in jail by a journalist who posed as a law clerk, and smuggled a television camera into the jail.</p><p> Afterwards, the journalist went to Queensland Police and told them what he had done.</p><p> He fled interstate when the police threatened to charge him and demanded he hand over his videotape of the interview.</p><p> In Sydney, homicide detectives are re-investigating the killing of a female hitchhiker, in a bid to determine whether she may have been the Belanglo serial killer's eighth victim, the first dumped outside the notorious forest.</p><p> Backpacker murder squad police are reviewing the murder of Dianne Pennacchio, found stabbed to death in a state forest almost 200km south of the Belanglo forest.</p><p> Detectives say the murder of the Queanbeyan mother, in September 1991, involved similar elements to several Belanglo killings.</p><p> Two detectives from Task Force Air spent the past week in Queanbeyan studying evidence from the Pennacchio case.</p><p> Mrs Pennacchio, 29, was last seen leaving a hotel at Bungendore, east of Canberra, to hitch a ride home to nearby Queanbeyan.</p><p> She never arrived Her badly decomposed body was found two months later in the Tallanganda State Forest, south of the Bungendore-Queanbeyan road.</p><p> Two forestry workers found the body face down, hidden alongside a log and covered with pine needles, about 10m from a forest fire trail.</p><p> Most of the Belanglo forest victims were found in almost identical positions and bushland settings.</p><p> Task Force Air commander Supt Clive Small said earlier that the similarity of the Belanglo body sites could well mark the "signature" of a serial killer.</p><p> Specialist officers would analyse the detailed findings so far, but Supt Small suggested a pattern already might be emerging from the nature and location of the death scenes.</p><p> Mrs Pennacchio was also savagely stabbed to death, as most of the Belanglo victims were believed to have died.</p><p> Police say there was no sign of a struggle where she was found, suggesting she was killed elsewhere and dumped at the forest site.</p><p> More than one person may have been involved because a lone killer would have found it hard to lift and carry her heavy frame.</p><p> Police also believe Mrs Pennacchio was probably sexually assaulted, based on the position of her jeans when found.</p><p> Some detectives believe that at least one of the Belanglo victims may have been sexually assaulted, and no signs of a struggle were found there, either.</p><p> If Mrs Pennacchio was murdered by the Belanglo forest killer, however, she was the only victim who was married and a mother, and not a backpacker.</p><p> A task force spokesman said that numerous other crime scenes had been visited by the squad's 35 detectives, but police have refused to name individual cases.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Flashback: Police in the Belanglo forest.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:3SNC-1600-0048-T1Y8-00000-00<published>1998-05-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WORLD NEWS IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">NIGERIA BABY</p><p nitf:lede="true"> LAGOS, May 10 Reuters - A spinning ceiling fan decapitated a five-month old Nigerian baby girl when a visiting relation tossed her in the air while playing, a local newspaper said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "The fan, said to be working at its maximum speed, reportedly severed the baby's head instantly," the Sunday Champion said. It said police in the southern town of Akure planned to charge the relation with murder.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The dead baby, named Bolatito, was her mother's first child after five years of trying to give birth, the paper said. It did not say when the incident happened.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>IRELAND MORTAR</p><p> LONDON, May 10 Reuters - A mortar bomb exploded during a security alert in a Northern Ireland village overnight but no one was injured, British radio and television reported.</p><p> The British Broadcasting Corporation, quoting police, said mortar tubes had been found near a number of holiday cottages in Belleek in the south of the British ruled province.</p><p> The apparent target was a police station, the BBC said.</p><p> A peace deal thrashed out in April would give Northern Ireland an elected assembly and strengthen its links with the Irish Republic, while ensuring that it remains part of Britain for as long as a majority so wishes.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>THAI BUDDHIST</p><p> BANGKOK, Thailand, May 10 AP - Millions of Buddhists across Thailand attended morning prayer services in grand, gold-studded and small, spare village temples to mark Visaka Bucha day today.</p><p> The holiday celebrates the birth, enlightenment and death of the religion's founder, the Buddha, which occurred on the same day in different years more than 2,500 years ago.</p><p>Thailand is more than 95 per cent Buddhist.</p><p> At dusk, worshippers will return to the temples where they will carry lit candles as they walk counterclockwise three times around the hall housing the temples' main Buddha image while chanting prayers in honour of the three events in the Buddha's life.</p><p> AP</p><p> NZ BRAWL</p><p>CHRISTCHURCH, May 10 NZPA - A teenage rugby match erupted into an all-out brawl between players, spectators, and parents here yesterday.</p><p> Up to 50 people were involved in fighting which broke out during a match at Hagley Park between the Hoon Hay and Shirley under-16 rugby teams. One parent was badly cut and bruised after several people kicked him as he lay on the ground.</p><p> Police said trouble started after the referee ended the game eight minutes early because of continuing aggression between the teams. One player had already been sent off following an incident on the field.</p><p> Fighting erupted when the teams were shaking hands at the end of the game, police said. Suddenly, all of the players were throwing punches, then the parents rushed on followed by the rest of the spectators.</p><p> NZPA</p><p>SAUDI DAM</p><p> RIYADH, May 10 AFP - Saudi Arabia has inaugurated the second largest dam in the Middle East, after Aswan in Egypt, at a cost of around $ US66 million ($ A104 million), newspapers reported today.</p><p> The all-concrete dam for agriculture and drinking water in the Bisha region of southwest Saudi Arabia, inaugurated yesterday by Crown Prince Abdallah ibn Abdel Aziz, has been named after King Fahd.</p><p> It has a capacity of 325 million cubic metres of water, measures 500 metres in length, 103 metres in height, and its wall is 80 metres thick.</p><p> The desert kingdom, which in 1984 achieved self-sufficiency in wheat production, now has a total of 206 dams.</p><p>AFP</p><p>THAI FIRE</p><p> BANGKOK, Thailand, May 10 AP - Thailand's Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai has ordered an investigation into rumours that government officials were involved in starting a forest fire that has raged out of control for weeks, The Nation newspaper reported today.</p><p> Chuan instructed provincial officials in Narathiwat, 1,140km southwest of Bangkok, to launch a probe into the persistent stories, although the prime minister expressed doubts about their veracity.</p><p> Chuan visited the area on Friday and yesterday to observe efforts to douse the flames.</p><p> The fire in a reserve in the southern province has burned stubbornly for weeks, destroying thousands of hectares of forest and wildlife habitat and leaving the province shrouded in haze.</p><p> AP</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    <br/></p><p> AAP shb</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SNC-1600-0048-T1Y8-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="711"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:3S3M-25M0-0048-T1XN-00000-00<published>1998-02-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: INDON FIRES RAGE AS MINISTERS SEEK SOLUTION TO HAZE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Kieron Flynn</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Feb 25 AFP - Fires raged in remote Indonesia forests today as regional environment ministers met to try to avoid a repeat of last year's choking haze which engulfed much of South-East Asia.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Estimates of the number of fires burning in East Kalimantan province alone ranged from 300 to more than 1,000, while dozens island.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Repeated water-bombing by aircraft and the dropping of fire-retardant chemicals had limited the scale of the problem in some of the worst hit areas of East Kalimantan, a firefighting official in the provincial capital of Samarinda said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "But more fires are starting and they are spreading," he added.</p><p>East Kalimantan governor H.M. Ardans said 2,700 hectares of the province were burning and more aerial bombing would be carried out this week.</p><p> Fire had razed 14,000 hectares of forest in East Kalimantan since January, he told the state Antara news agency.</p><p> Centre for International Forestry Research analyst Fred Stolle said the situation would worsen without rain because of a prolonged drought as a result of the El Nino weather pattern.</p><p> However, recent rainfall had minimised the risk of fires spreading in Riau, he added. "For Sumatra, there is no problem," Stolle said. "We are not at the same level as last year. But if there is no rain in East Kalimantan it could be even worse than last year."</p><p> The head of a German-funded fire-fighting program earlier said fires in East Kalimantan were already too big and widespread to contain.</p><p> "It is really bad," Integrated Forest Fire Management Project chief Ludwig Schindler said late on Monday. "The area is completely covered with haze. There is no way to fly. Visibility is down to 300 metres.</p><p> "These fires have escalated to the extent that makes it impossible, or economically impossible, to put them out. The only thing that could help now is rain."</p><p> The fires were raging in a 250 kilometre band straddling the Mahakam River in central East Kalimantan, he added.</p><p> The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) today estimated the regional bill for damage caused by the Indonesian fires and the subsequent haze in 1997 was almost $ US1.5 billion ($ A2.26 billion).</p><p> Damage estimated at $ US1 billion ($ A1.51 billion) was sustained by Indonesia itself, 90 per cent of that figure in short-term health costs, the group said in a statement issued by its Jakarta office.</p><p> Another $ US90 million ($ A135.68 million) was lost in tourism and airport shutdowns.</p><p>Malaysia lost about $ US300 million ($ A452.28 million), mainly in lost industrial production and a slump in tourism as the haze spread from its bigger neighbour.</p><p>Singapore lost $ US60 million ($ A90.46 million), mainly in tourism receipts. It and Malaysia paid out a combined $ US12 million ($ A18.09 million) for additional health care directly attributed to the choking smog, which affected some 70 million people in the region, the statement said.</p><p> The figures were compiled in a survey conducted by WWF and the Singapore-based Economy and Environment Program for South-East Asia.</p><p> The dwindling orangutan population, confined to Sumatra and the Indonesian and Malaysian sections of Borneo island, was in danger of extinction as the fires stole their natural habitat and were replaced by plantations, WWF said.</p><p> "The orangutan is already under heavy threat from forest clearing and hunting," said WWF's Barita Manullang. "These fires may well be the final push towards extinction."</p><p> The fires, largely blamed on land clearing by Indonesian plantation and timber firms, sent thick haze over Singapore, parts of Malaysia and even distant Thailand for several months last year.</p><p> ASEAN environment ministers were holding a one-day meeting in the Malaysian city of Kuching today to discuss joint measures against the fires.</p><p>Malaysian Science, Technology and Environment Minister Law Hieng Ding said the Indonesian fires had already affected parts of Sarawak state bordering East Kalimantan on the island of Borneo.</p><p> Law said the ministers from the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) would review progress in formulating a "regional haze action plan" and the status of assistance from the Manila-based Asian Development Bank.</p><p>Indonesian Environment Minister Sarwono Kusumaatmadja said cloud-seeding could begin tomorrow in a bid to contain the East Kalimantan fires.</p><p>AFP jnb</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S3M-25M0-0048-T1XN-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="734"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:49K2-M930-01S8-G4DG-00000-00<published>1986-11-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LEAD WOMEN PUT LIFE IN HARD ROLES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>TEERDS J</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Lead women put life in hard roles Among the deluge of Christmas video releases, there are several good movies which easily could be overlooked in the rush.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Here's two, both biographical films, to keep an eye out for. One, Sweet Dreams, is on country singer Patsy Cline; the other, Second Serve, is on sex-change tennis player Dr Renee Richards.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Both feature particularly compelling performances from the lead players, Jessica Lange and Vanessa Redgrave respectively.</p><p>Even if you don't like country music, Sweet Dreams, from Cannon, is a highly watchable film, with Lange giving a fine portrayal as Cline from her early days as a singer in a bar to her tragic death in a plane crash.</p><p>Ed Harris as her lover and second husband is excellent, and adds a lot of life to the film's leisurely pace.</p><p>In Second Serve, from Lorimar Home Video, Redgrave is totally convincing as the male eye-surgeon who yields to a lifelong desire to become a woman. The film could have been ""tacky", but the subject is deftly and sensitively handled, and Redgrave's transformation from male to female is stunning.</p><p>Second Serve should be available now from most video outlets; Sweet Dreams should become available during the week.</p><p>Elvis Presley fans will be able to buy five of the King's films on video from this week.</p><p>CBS/Fox Video is releasing Love Me Tender, G.I. Blues, Fun in Acapulco, Flaming Star and Blue Hawaii, all with a hi-fi soundtrack and all at a recommended price of $29.95 each.</p><p>Purchasers also will have the opportunity to win a trip for two to Graceland, Presley's home in Memphis, Tennessee.</p><p>CBS/Fox also is releasing Billy Joel, The Video Album Vol. I, featuring songs such as Piano Man, All for Leyna, Tell Her About It, A Matter of Trust and Keepin' the Faith, and Wham in China, which includes concert and travel footage from the group's visit.</p><p>The Joel cassette will retail for $22.95 while Wham in China will cost $29.95.</p><p>Other releases include four Voltron cartoon adventures for children (RRP $19.95 each), Green and Gold Greats Vols I and II ($29.95 each) and Everyday with Richard Simmons for fitness fans ($19.95).</p><p>Twice in a Lifetime, a touching film about a man who falls in love with another woman after 30 years of marriage, leads this month's rental releases from CEL.</p><p>It stars Ann-Margaret, Gene Hackman and Ellen Burstyn.</p><p>CEL's other November releases include The Chain, about the pitfalls of moving house, Forbidden, about a German countess who falls in love with a Jew, Mussolini and I, starring Bob Hoskins in the title role, Solo, about a young Australian hitchhiker and her relationship with a pilot and forest fire-watcher, and Night Games, about a woman who becomes involved in a world of sexual fantasies.</p><p>national top 10 1. Spies Like Us.</p><p>2. Teen Wolf.</p><p>3. Delta Force.</p><p>4. Mischief.</p><p>5. Troll.</p><p>6. Prizzi's Honor.</p><p>7. Weird Science.</p><p>8. Agnes of God.</p><p>9. Bad Guys.</p><p>10. Death Wish III.</p><p>Courtesy Video Week magazine VANESSA REDGRAVE as Dr Renee Richards . . . compelling.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC SHOWS VANESSA REDGRAVE AS DR RENEE RICHARDS</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7TYJ-NFW0-Y9Y8-S10N-00000-00Townships under ember attack as fires rage2009-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisTownships under ember attack as fires rage

Embers are falling on townships which are being threatened by a fierce bushfire which is burning out of control and threatening power lines east of Melbourne.

Fires are raging across Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales, with tens of thousands of fire fighters on stand-by across all three states.

The fire in Bunyip State Park is now within a kilometre of major transmission lines that feed power to the Victorian capital.

Victorian fire authorities say the townships of Labertouche and Labertouche North are coming under ember attack and Stuart Ord the Department of Sustainability and Environment says the fire could threaten homes.

"Those communities in particular, Labertouche, Jindivick, Neerim and Tonimbuk, would be seeing smoke at the moment coming from the fire further back," he said.

"We're expecting the temperatures to get into the mid-40s today and this afternoon, and we're expecting the wind speeds to increase, so as that happens, the speed of this fire will increase."

The Victorian Ambulance Service is evacuating people from aged care homes at Neerim and Bunyip.

Hottest day

Melbourne has already recorded its hottest-ever February day, with the temperature in the city reaching 46 degrees Celsius at 2:27pm (AEDT).

The mercury reached 47.4 degrees at Avalon between Melbourne and Geelong at 2:41pm, while 46.8 degrees was recorded at Laverton.

In regional areas, it reached 46 degrees at Mildura, 46 at Yarrawonga and 45.3 at Aireys Inlet.

Residents of Kilmore East, Wandong and Clonbinane north of Melbourne are on alert, as strong northerly winds fan a fire in the area.

The fire is currently burning three kilometres east of Kilmore, near Saunders Road. The CFA says the fire is gaining strength as it heads towards pine plantations near Wandong.

The Hume Highway has been closed south of Kilmore.

ABC reporter James Bennet says residents in the area have been prepapring for the fire's arrival.

"Certainly the state here for residents is one of really realising that it is indeed time to go," he said.

"This fire is extremely close, flames are visible from the hillside and it can't be too long before the fire will be encroaching on several of these houses."

More Vic fires

Another fire is burning a kilometre south of Churchill in the Latrobe Valley and is throwing embers and spotfires toward Hazelwood South, Jeeralang, Jeeralang North and Balook. Concerns are also held for Traralgon South.

The CFA has told residents of numerous towns that could be threatened by bushfires to immediately enact their bushfire survival plans.

A fire burning near Coleraine, in Victoria's south-west, has crossed the Coleraine-Balmoral Road after earlier jumping the Glenelg Highway.

The fire is heading east and residents of Muntham, Coleraine and Hilgay are being warned to be on alert.

A grass fire east of Camperdown is posing a threat to homes on Scollers Road and Caters Roads, as well as the community of Swan Marsh.

The CFA says a blaze on south-east of Churchill in Gippsland could pose a threat to residents of Jerralang, Jerralang North and Jerralang Junction.

A fire is also burning on the southern outskirts of Horsham, in the state's north-west, and the CFA says people in the communities of Haven, McKenzie Creek and Wonwondah should be patrolling their homes for burning embers.

V-Line has suspended train services on the Warrnambool, Gippsland and Seymour lines because of bushfires.

For information on the Victorian fires call the Country Fire Authority's information line on 1800 240 667.

Power has been cut to 700 homes across suburban Melbourne, but authorities say they expect it to be restored within hours.

Homes in Brighton, Oakleigh, Parkdale and Templestowe are most affected, with high winds causing damage to power lines.

South Australia

The South Australian Country Fire Service (CFS) says a fire at Gawler River, in Adelaide's north, is threatening public safety.

The fire started near Wilkinson Road and Gawler River Road and is travelling in a south-easterly direction towards Munno Para, Kudla, Hillier and Angle Vale.

The CFS says smoke and burning embers could threaten people's safety and property.

The public is being advised not to enter the area as access is restricted.

Wind gusts of up to 90 kilometres per hour are predicted, along with temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius.

It was already 37C in Adelaide at 9:00am ACDT.

More than 10,000 firefighters and 11 water bombers are on stand-by in strategic positions around the state.

One water bomber has already been sent to help contain a forest fire at Nangwarry near Mount Gambier.

National parks at Mount Lofty and on the Fleurieu Peninsula are closed because of the bushfire threat, and Monarto Zoo is also closed.

The SES emergency number is 132 500 and the South Australian Country Fire Service information hotline is 1300 362 361.

New South Wales

A fire in Wollemi National Park in the New South Wales Hunter region has been declared a bushfire emergency.

The Rural Fire Service says three fires which began in the park this morning have joined up, burning about 1,000 hectares of bushland, but it is not threatening any properties.

Forty firefighters and two aircraft have been trying to put the fire out and the emergency declaration will free up more resources.

RFS spokeswoman Rebel Talbert says there are more than 40 fires burning across the state, with particular concern about blazes in Bega Valley, Tumut and the Shoalhaven.

The RFS says a bushfire in the Bega Valley in the state's far south has crossed containment lines.

The blaze has burnt over 1,000 hectares since it began about a week ago at Jingera Rock.

While it is not currently threatening any properties residents from nearby villages including Towamba, Wyndham and Burragate have been asked to stay prepared.

A spokeswoman says water bombers have been deployed to fight the blaze.

On the central coast Lake Munmorah Park has been closed because of a fire burning there. The New South Wales Rural Fire Service information hotline is 1800 679 737.

A weekend-long total fire ban has been issued in Canberra.

Many of Canberra's public parks have been closed as a precaution, with gas bottles turned off at public barbeques.

A number of roads in the Namadgi National Park have been closed, while Googong Foreshores will also be closed.
