urn:contentItem:4P89-SFP0-TXN5-V34W-00000-00Fire service `let me down'1999-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Fire service `let me down'Wingello survivor recalls horrorJENNY DENNIS

One of the seven surviving Wingello firefighters yesterday told a coroner's inquest in Bowral he felt let down by the Rural Fire Service.

"I put my faith in what I supposed were the experts and I guess I feel let down," said Roger Robinson.

Outside the court Mr Robinson said by "the experts" he meant the RFS and its commissioner Phil Koperberg.

A volunteer firefighter for just four years, Mr Robinson was the least experienced of the seven men and one woman sent into Wingello State Forest on New Year's Day 1998 to do a back-burn.

Minutes after the back-burn had begun, their tanker - Wingello One - was engulfed by a massive firestorm, leaving the tanker driver David Quinlivan dead and the seven other crew members severely burnt.

The inquest into Mr Quinlivan's death began in February before Coroner John Abernathy.

It is sitting again this week in Bowral Courthouse.

Mr Robinson, one of the last of the surviving firefighters to give evidence, said he thought he was going to die in the fire.

"I was praying," he said. "The heat was like a hot oven."

Mr Robinson, who was yesterday still wearing pressure bandages on his burnt hands, was critical of equipment firefighters were issued at the time. He said he went into the back-burn without gloves.

"I didn't have gloves because they weren't at that time something that was issued," he said.

"The part I find most upsetting is that half the time you have to buy it (the equipment) yourself."

When the crew bedded down under fire blankets in a desperate attempt to escape the flames, Mr Robinson and fellow crew member John Luke had to share one blanket.

During earlier evidence the RFS manager of engineering services, Richard Donarski, said that by the time the 1999 fire season got under way all RFS vehicles would carry a safety blanket for each person on board.

He said a CSIRO study carried out in the wake of the Wingello tragedy was expected to be completed by October.

"To the best of our knowledge, at the present time, we believe we have an effective system, but we won't really know until the CSIRO testing is complete," Mr Donarski added.

He said the results of that scientific evaluation would attract worldwide interest as it would be the first of its kind.

Mr Donarski said the RFS introduced a vehicular spray system in 1984 after the Grays Point fire in Sutherland Shire.

"At this point in time, to the best of our knowledge, that system does work because we haven't had a situation where we have lost a vehicle with the spray system fitted."

Wingello One, built in 1980, had no spray system.

However, Mr Donarski said he believed even the most up-to-date spray systems would have failed in the conditions experienced at Wingello that day.

"Under the known spray systems we are currently utilising it would have basically given them a false sense of security," he said.

Also giving evidence yesterday was Wingello One's captain Mike Neale who broke down in tears when asked to recall that day in the forest.

Mr Neale's evidence conflicted with other members of his crew who had said the tanker was forced to reverse back along a fire trail after a forestry commission vehicle travelling ahead of it lost traction and rolled backwards.

Minutes later Wingello One was engulfed, according to other members of the crew.

But yesterday Mr Neale maintained that when he saw the forestry commission vehicle it was facing the tanker.

He said he watched through the tanker's window as the forestry vehicle's driver, Graham McDonald, took cover under a blanket.

"If the crew's assertions that the vehicle was backing towards you are correct, you must, with the greatest respect, have imagined seeing Mr McDonald in the window," said Robert Sutherland, counsel for Mr McDonald.

"If they are correct," Mr Neale said.

The inquest continues today.

Two illus: In his evidence volunteer firefighter Roger Robinson said he felt ``let down by the experts'' after the devastating forest fire at Wingello on January 1, 1998. Picture: SOUTHERN HIGHLANDS NEWS RFS manager of engineering services Richard Donarski (right) discusses a new RFS fire tanker fitted with a spray system outside Bowral Courthouse yesterday. Picture: SOUTHERN HIGHLANDS NEWS

   CANBERRA - The federal government is sticking to its unemployment forecast of 6.75 per cent for next year, despite an unexpected drop in the jobless rate to 5.7 per cent. (Jobs Gillard)

   Liberals Wrap to come

   TO COME: Bushfires NSW Wrap, Bushfires Qld Wrap

   ABS Health Wrap, Factbox to come
  
   SYDNEY - A child protection agency was more concerned with the welfare of Rachel Pfitzner than with the infant son she eventually murdered, the NSW Ombudsman says. (Shillingsworth Update)
   Shillingsworth Wrap to come
  
   BRISBANE - The founder of one of Australia's best known child protection organisations says she may be forced to quit her job because of a lack of government funding. (Bravehearts)  
   Bravehearts Wrap to come
  
   BRISBANE - Five men and four teenage boys have been committed to stand trial for the murder of rugby league star Johnathan Thurston's uncle. (Saunders)
  
   SYDNEY - Grocery wholesaler Metcash has succeeded in its bid to enter the hardware market by winning agreement to buy 50.1 per cent of Mitre 10 for $55 million. (Metcash)
   Metcash Wrap to come
  
   COOLUM - Korean Min-Kyu Han ripped the new Hyatt Coolum course apart with a record first round of nine-under-par 62 in the Australian PGA Championship. (Golf Aust Update)
   Golf Aust Wrap to come

   AUCKLAND - In a country more at home with colourful shirts than colourful language, a politician has sparked a furore across deeply conservative and religious Samoa by calling the parliamentary speaker a testicle. (Samoa Balls)
  
   SYDNEY - Australian scientists can soon resume their research into the controversial field of animal to human transplants, because the nation's five-year moratorium will be allowed to lapse. (Transplants)

   CANBERRA - The Rudd government has denied preferencing Labor seats when handing out money for job-boosting community projects, despite new figures suggesting otherwise. (Fund Gillard. )

   MELBOURNE - An application to call the aged mother of suspected serial child killer Derek Ernest Percy before a coronial inquest into the disappearance of a seven-year-old girl 41 years ago has been rejected. (Stilwell. Wrap to come)
  
   MELBOURNE - A Victorian Labor MP will be given a dressing down by the premier after he was slapped with a suspended jail sentence for driving while disqualified. (Somyurek. Wrap to come)
  
   MELBOURNE - A sleep-deprived truck driver who ploughed into stopped traffic on a Melbourne freeway, killing a man, has been jailed for three years. (Hodge. Wrap to come)

   MELBOURNE - A man has been arrested over the bashing murder of a Melbourne musician. (Park)
  
   BRISBANE - Sabotage is being examined as the possible cause of a series of southeast Queensland rail network shutdowns but Transport Minister Rachel Nolan says she has full confidence in the workforce. (Rail Qld Update. wrap to come)
  
   BRISBANE - Queensland has taken just 150 years to grow into a prosperous community with huge potential for the future, a ceremony in Brisbane marking 150 years since the colony was officially separated from NSW has been told. (Q150. Wrap to come)
  
   BRISBANE - A man believed to be celebrating his 70th birthday has died in a tragic skydiving accident. (Skydive. More expected)
  
   BRISBANE - Two bass fish leapt over a 36 metre dam wall in an incredible 260km journey to breeding grounds in southeast Queensland, new research has revealed. (Bass)
  
   BRISBANE - A man protesting in a union picket line outside Brisbane's BP refinery has been taken to hospital in an ambulance after he was struck by a vehicle. (Petrol Update. Wrap to come)
  
   BRISBANE - More than 100 mine workers have rallied outside the Brisbane headquarters of Peabody Energy after the company locked out its workforce at a central Queensland coal mine. (Peabody)
  
   ADELAIDE - A mining industry group has asked the federal government to clarify which areas of South Australia's Woomera weapons testing range can be explored and mined. (Woomera )
  
   ADELAIDE - Carbon neutral wines produced in South Australia's Clare Valley will be served at an official function at the Copenhagen Climate Change conference on Thursday. (Summit Wines )

urn:contentItem:4N3H-0G90-TX52-K31G-00000-00Message must get through2007-02-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 14Message must get through

I HAVE just read Ross Moyle's graphic article regarding wild dog attacks ''Terror reign must cease'' (WT, February 14).

As a regional reader of The Weekly Times I can only hope this article, and the associated picture, is shown in major metropolitan newspapers.

Otherwise, we are only preaching to the converted.

Neville Harvey,

Shepparton

Traps not the answer

WHILE the images of sheep mauled by wild dogs are pitiful (WT, February 14, page 17) so is Chris Rule's cartoon ridiculing those who wish to see more humane methods for controlling these dogs (WT, February 14, page 7).

Equally pitiful are the images on the RSPCA's website of wild dogs trapped by steel-jawed traps.

Wild dogs are apparently ''exempt'' from the cruelty laws which protect other species.

Steel-jawed traps, while generally banned in Victoria, are amazingly still permitted for use on these dogs, with no legal requirement for the traps to be checked daily. Thus the dogs may languish for days.

The RSPCA states that it is: ''not opposed to lethal control methods for pest animals provided that there is justification for such killing and there is no effective humane non-lethal alternative method available. It is, however, opposed to any method of control that does not result in a humane death''.

The suffering of sheep and the loss to farmers clearly cannot continue. However, this does not justify inflicting prolonged suffering on an animal just because it is a ''pest''.

If wild dogs must be trapped, then this should be done under a mandatory code of practice whereby, at the very least, traps are checked daily and the steel-jawed trap banned.

More preventative measures could perhaps be considered, like the use of Maremma sheepdogs to protect sheep flocks.

Jenny Atkins,

Kilcunda

Dairy model unsustainable

THE current dairy industry model we now have, where Dairy Australia is a leading body and voice of the dairy farmers, has become outdated and no longer provides us, the levy payers, with the direction or results which we so desperately require.

I have been fortunate to meet some people involved in Dairy Australia who have been totally committed and driven to achieve results for farmers but the current business structure will always impede the process.

The Australian ownership of the processing factories has continued to decline and the once strong co-op sector has and is reducing at a rate which will see the majority of milk processed by mostly overseas-owned companies.

The dairy industry as we know it will only survive in this country if a much more focused and responsive attitude is taken to product research and development beyond the farm gate.

Milk pre farm gate is produced in the country already at a world competitive price and to commit money year after year into programs and research will have very minimal impact on returns, as has been the case over many years.

Every year management beyond the farm gate continues to improve and reduce production costs, but the only chance for farmers to make a real gain in milk price is to deliver higher valued products to the consumer.

Consumers will always pay for what they see as good value and more money must be directed to delivering higher valued products.

The wool industry is a classic example of a big budget marketing and promotion approach, but failed to develop their commodity into a must-have product.

They are now paying a very dear price for this.

It is now time for the manufacturing sector to show some maturity and take some responsibility for research marketing and promotion of their own lines, and to put an end to dairy farmers' ''feel good'' blanket approach to dairy food advertising -- which at best may only slightly influence consumers rather than inspiring and motivating them.

A change of this nature will inject more enthusiasm and energy into our industry, as people are more motivated and productive when new and innovative products are coming forward.

This is what will attract a younger workforce to the whole dairy sector, as we all link our job satisfaction and contentment to being part of a progressive modern and profitable industry.

I will be voting to discontinue the paying of a dairy service levy, in order to move the industry forward.

I encourage all dairy farmers to carefully consider the options available to them as we are the ones that are, in the end, responsible for our destiny.

Ross Berryman,

Leongatha

Industry is crucial

OF 15,000ha of forest in the Yarra tributaries, only 60-70ha is harvested a year.

Of the 50,000ha in the Thompson catchment, only 12,000ha is available for harvesting of which a maximum 150ha is harvested on an annual basis.

The quality timber from this forest is the lifeblood for many regional towns. To end harvesting would result in the closure of sawmills and job losses.

The timber workers who make up these communities are quite often the backbone of local CFAs. If their jobs go, so will they.

Harvesting contractors, like their CFA counterparts, also provide expertise in fire fighting. Their machinery has been the difference between a small forest fire and a major wildfire.

The timber industry has provided the road network that allows better access to fires. They are the ones protecting our catchments from fire.

It would be a cruel twist of fate if the forests that environmentalists had believed they were saving, burnt, because the machinery and people had gone.

Scott Gentle,

Victorian state manager,

Timber Communities Australia

Victorians want the truth

THE level of concern expressed through The Weekly Times by those who live, work and enjoy our public land, firmly indicates that Victorians are demanding more than reassurances from biased bureaucrats ''Bushfire criticism uncalled for'' (WT, January 24) that the world's best practice is being applied to public land management.

However, we do not need another politicised inquiry. Victorians deserve a Royal Commission.

We need the truth before any more of our endangered fauna is burnt to a crisp.

Rita Bentley,

president,

Prospectors & Miners

Association of Victoria

urn:contentItem:44XD-KVD0-015G-S2X2-00000-00<published>2002-01-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 1</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BACKFIRED - This MP accused our firefighters of being reckless -- but he burned down 2ha of state forest</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SIMON BENSON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE senior Coalition MP accusing fire authorities of negligence has burned down two hectares of state forest, The Daily Telegraph has learned.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Andrew Fraser, the Coalition's special adviser on rural affairs, last night admitted he had been careless and wished it had never happened.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It was an accident. I can understand why people might be upset," the National Party MP said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Seven rural fire brigade units and 25 volunteers were called to the incident late last year when Mr Fraser tried to burn off a paddock on his Coffs Harbour property.</p><p> The incident, which has angered senior fire authorities, comes after revelations that more than 20 per cent of fires in national parks are started on private property or other lands -- many from burn-offs.</p><p> Only 4 per cent of fires every year in NSW occur in national parks.</p><p> An incident report, obtained by The Daily Telegraph, show the fire on Mr Fraser's property escaped into the Lower Bucca State Forest, destroying 2ha.</p><p> "I blame the wind change," Mr Fraser said last night.</p><p> "I lit the fire in the morning against my normal better judgment … I had a meeting in the afternoon and I would normally</p><p>From Page 1</p><p>do that sort of thing late in the day. It taught me a very valuable lesson.</p><p> "My carelessness was lighting the fire in the morning.</p><p> "I would love for it not to have happened. I would have loved to have not called the rural fire service out, but these things happen."</p><p> But volunteer firefighters are outraged that Mr Fraser has accused them and the National Parks and Wildlife Service of not conducting enough hazard reduction to prevent the Christmas bushfire crisis.</p><p>Rural Fire Services Commissioner Phil Koperberg, when pressed for</p><p> a comment last night, said: "The incident has come to my attention in the past few days.</p><p> "Given the difficulties volunteers have to face on a daily basis, I am disappointed that someone who purports to be aware of the hazards, would allow a situation to develop where property was endangered and volunteers were called to suppress a fire."</p><p> The outspoken MP has led the charge of recent criticism of Mr Koperberg and the NPWS, claiming it was "negligent" for not doing enough hazard reduction.</p><p> He has also accused that the RFS should have done more as well.</p><p> Last night, a senior volunteer firefighter who attended the fire said it had been left unattended.</p><p> "[Mr Fraser] left the fire unattended and went in and got a cup of coffee," the senior officer said.</p><p> "If there wasn't full crews down there it would have got off right through the state forest.</p><p> "It could have been a lot worse … it was lucky that there were two brigades doing a hazard reduction burn nearby and we called them in for help.</p><p> "We threw everything we had at it."</p><p> Mr Fraser and his 15-year-old son started the burn-off which he claimed he was required to do by law.</p><p> Mr Fraser said he asked his wife to make an emergency call to the Rural Fire Service when they realised it was out of control.</p><p> The incident was reported to the Rural Fire Service at Coffs Harbour at 11.04am on August 4, 2001.</p><p> The report concluded: "Owners burning off pile of logs/trees. Fire escaped into grassy paddock and some state forest."</p><p> Fire units were called to the emergency from four brigades in the region, including Bucca, Coramba, Nana Glen and Moonee.</p><p> The first units arrived at 11.17am and battled the blaze until 2.32pm.</p><p> Mr Fraser did not required a permit for the burn-off.</p><p> "It is our dry season and the wind was blowing from the northwest," said another volunteer who attended the fire.</p><p> "I would say it was an act of gross negligence.</p><p> "I would not have been putting a match near anything on a day like that.</p><p> "He should have known better."</p><p>Words of wisdom</p><p>Andrew Fraser, National Party MP, criticising the National Parks and Wildlife Service:</p><p>  *  "Let's get out there and sensibly remove bushfire hazards from behind residential areas." on 2WS, January 4</p><p>  * "I believe the NPWS has been very negligent in their attitude towards hazard reduction burning."same interview</p><p>  * "I would hope we don't get this collective statement that says hazard reduction is not the panacea, its been said by Mr Carr, its been said by Mr Debus, it's been said by Mr Gilligan (NPWS) and it's been said by Mr Koperberg." same interview</p><p>  * "One can only wonder … when a class action is taken against the Government and NPWS for their gross negligence ..." press release January 3, 2002</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4592-1TH0-0197-823W-00000-00<published>1999-02-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 136</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Oh boy, Scouts take the cake</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Peter Ruehl</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The Boy Scouts are serving me up a plateful of correctness over the next few days, but I think they've gotten it wrong.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Actually, it's the Cub Scouts, which is what you put your kid into when you know he'd start a forest fire if he had to cook a hotdog on his own.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Boy Scouts are about camping, hiking and not having sex with anyone of any species until you are really tired of camping and hiking. Cub Scouts are about occupying younger boys' time in between school and home-wrecking.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>So, I've got my two boys - Tom, 7, and Jack, 8 - in the Cubs. They go to den meetings and recently designed scale-model racing cars which had to meet certain length and weight specifications, which was a valuable experience for them in that we had to figure out other ways to cheat in order to win the races.</p><p> (When I was a Cub, we did artsy-craftsy stuff like making our mothers water-sprinkling dispensers to help with their ironing. This really seemed like a weenie waste of time until, several year later, I noticed my father had appropriated the thing, filled it with vermouth and was using it to make extra dry martinis.) Anyway, the annual Cub Scout dinner is this week. This is, by the way, how kids' activities work.</p><p>The boys have been Cub Scouts for nine weeks and we've already got an annual dinner. I figure by April we'll be looking at the Lifetime Achievement Awards.</p><p> The catch is that each Cub has to show up with a homemade cake, and "fathers and sons must bake -no assistance from mothers allowed".  This is a big mistake, if you ask me. I'm married to a professional woman and I know lots of other women who also have full-time jobs. The one thing most of them have in common is the concern they show for their husbands' welfare by not cooking for them.</p><p> I mean, if the Cubs really wanted to create a handicap, they'd write in a proviso: "Assistance from mothers with high IQs and responsible jobs required." The cakes would look like Jack Palance's face and you'd need concrete reinforcement for the table they were on.</p><p> Professional women don't have time to cook and most of them chose kick-boxing when they had the option to learn in high school. When I first met my wife, for example, she was living in an apartment in New York City.</p><p>We went to her place and, when I flipped on the kitchen light, 2.3 million cockroaches scuttled to the relative safety of Chernobyl.</p><p> Then I looked in the refrigerator and I could see why the roaches hit the road. The contents consisted of one jar of Vegemite.</p><p> I couldn't figure out how she survived until I subsequently learned she was on a first-name basis with every up-market carry-out in mid-town Manhattan.</p><p> You single guys watch out when they tell you they can cook Asian food, especially Thai. My wife and others worked this scam on me.</p><p> They heat up the food with so much seasoning you wouldn't know whether you were eating a spring roll or swallowing the exhaust manifold of a Harley Davidson.</p><p> On the other hand there's always the possibility they really can cook but just want to get out of it.</p><p> The other night, for example, we had eight people over for dinner and my wife cooked the meal.</p><p> I was ready with the fire extinguisher, a gun and the rescue squad phone number already recorded on the redial.</p><p> It turned out to be an excellent meal and now these people think I get this sort of thing cooked for me every night of the week.</p><p> What they don't know is that if I didn't enjoy barbecuing, my wife, the kids and I would look like a poster family for UNICEF.</p><p> I still haven't figured out the cake for the Cubs.</p><p> Cakes aren't my -as we gastronomic people say forte.</p><p> My wife has strenuously objected to one of my favorite old recipes -Velvet Underground Brownies which I had hoped would lighten up the event.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4GST-2K30-015G-X1W9-00000-00<published>2005-08-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SUPPLEMENT; Pg. D11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Stan James rates this week's TV movies</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Stan James</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Today</p><p nitf:lede="true">Rain</p><p nitf:lede="true">2001, 10pm, SBS ***</p><p nitf:lede="true">Set during a New Zealand beachside holiday in 1972, the relationship between an impressionable teenager and her mother is examined at a leisurely yet involving pace. It focuses on the collapsing marriage of Kate (Sarah Pierse) and Ed (Alistair Browning). Watching is their sexually emerging 13-year-old daughter Janey (Alicia Fulford-Wierzbicki), who loves and cares for her younger brother, Jim (Aaron Murphy). The story slowly builds an expectancy of trouble.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Thursday</p><p nitf:lede="true">Don Juan De Marco</p><p nitf:lede="true">1995, 6.20pm, Movie Extra/Foxtel ***</p><p>At 71, Marlon Brando returned to the screen as burnt-out psychiatrist Jack Mickler. Yet, despite being overweight with a speech impediment, he retains charisma. He's about to retire, has lost touch with his wife (Faye Dunaway) and is called on to talk a young, would-be suicide (Johnny Depp) to safety. Dressed in cape, mask and waving a sword, the young man claims to be Don Juan and Mickler has 10 days to treat him.</p><p>Friday</p><p>Home Alone</p><p>1990, 8.30pm, Seven ***</p><p>One of the most popular films of all time, an improbable story of little Kevin, played with gusto and charm by Macaulay Culkin, who is accidentally left home by his family as they rush off on holiday. After a slow buildup, it turns into slapstick farce as two thieves (Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern) try to rob the house and meet the force of Kevin's tricks and traps. Meanwhile, mum (Catherine O'Hara), dad (John Heard) and family desperately try to solve the crisis.</p><p>Firestorm</p><p>1998, 10.45pm, Seven *</p><p>Oscar-winning cinematographer Dean Semler's uninspiring directorial debut isn't helped by former American football star Howie Long as Wyoming firefighter Jesse Graves who leads a team of smoke-jumpers who parachute into forest fires. During a forest fire, a killer (William Forsythe) escapes from prison, joins convicts fighting the fire and grabs $36 million in stashed loot. Scott Glenn is a veteran firefighter who discovers the escape just as a firestorm is created.</p><p>Saturday</p><p>The Wedding Planner</p><p>2001, 7.30pm, Nine ***</p><p>Pleasant fairytale romance with Jennifer Lopez as a popular wedding planner who hasn't found time for the right man. Enter Matthew McConaughey, who saves her from being hit by a runaway truck. It's love. But he's about to marry a tycoon's daughter and she's arranging it. It's enjoyable, filled with familiar situations but Lopez is out of her depth as a supposed bitter love cynic.</p><p>Bad Boys</p><p>1995, 10pm, Ten ***</p><p>A dynamic romp beginning with a $100 million police haul of heroin. The script isn't original but its energy and dynamic visual style belt it along. Martin Lawrence and Will Smith are Miami drug squad members. Lawrence is married with three children while Smith is a wealthy bachelor, with a Porsche and luxury apartment. A key murder witness (Tea Leoni) must be protected and Lawrence is forced to pretend he's Smith to protect her.</p><p>D.O.A</p><p>1988, 11.50pm, Nine **</p><p>This is the second remake of the 1949 film noir thriller which starred Edmond O'Brien. Dennis Quaid and Meg Ryan star in this flashy, too clever, frantic version. Quaid is a college professor fed a slow poison that is killing him. In desperation against the clock - and with the help of Ryan - he tries to find out who has "killed" him and why.</p><p>Sunday</p><p>Two Weeks Notice</p><p>2002, 8.30pm, Nine ***</p><p>Romantic comedy, with Hugh Grant teamed with Sandra Bullock in a by-the-numbers operation with Grant's golly-gosh routine against Bullock's tomboy determination. Although it's light on laughs, there's an undercurrent of amusing charm. Bullock is a brilliant environmentalist lawyer fighting millionaire developer Grant. But she becomes his chief lawyer at $250,000 a year because she will distribute the company's charity funds.</p><p>X-Men</p><p>2000, 10.30pm, Seven ***</p><p>Adapted from the best-selling American comic-book series, it's war in the near future as an elitist band of mutants, led by Ian McKellen, take on a more humane bunch of mutants, led by Patrick Stewart. It's a lively and comic splash of stunning visuals, outlandish characters and simple, humane philosophy about everyone getting on with each other along with Wolverine, played dynamically by Hugh Jackman.</p><p>Jacob's Ladder</p><p>1990, 11.30pm, Ten **</p><p>Director Adrian Lynne has an indulgent time with Tim Robbins as Vietnam veteran Jacob who has nightmares about an enemy attack. He separated from his wife after the death of his young son (uncredited Macauley Culkin). He lives with a co-worker, Jezzie (Elizabeth Pena) in a strained relationship. Grim reality shatters the surreality when it seems Vietnam veterans involved in the attack are being murdered in car bombings. Then there is more confusion and the script becomes too smart when Jacob is kidnapped by government officials.</p><p>Monday</p><p>Madeleine</p><p>1950, 1.30am, ABC-TV **</p><p>Ann Todd is impressive as a young woman in Victorian Glasgow accused of murdering her secret lover. Despite a strong cast (Leslie Banks, Elizabeth Sellars), the script lacks dramatic punch. That can't be overcome despite Todd's then-husband director David Lean's cinematic storytelling skills and the mood-creating black-and-white photography.</p><p>Tuesday</p><p>The Battle of Algiers ***</p><p>1965, 8pm, World Movies/Foxtel</p><p>The penultimate in the 25 Films You Must See Before You Die  series, a passionate pseudo-documentary of the Algerian revolt against the French from 1954-62. An involving propaganda exercise, it won the Golden Lion award at the Venice Film Festival.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P0N-JX50-TXN5-S1TD-00000-00Versatile poetry of reflection and doubt2003-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 5Versatile poetry of reflection and doubtBOOKS - POETRYGig Ryan, Reviewer

BOOK REVIEWS: MANGROVES, By Laurie Duggan, UQP, $21.95; A BREAK IN THE WEATHER, John Jenkins, Modern Writing Press, $19.95

Science and scientists have set the scene in two recent verse novels - John Jenkins's A Break in the Weather and Dorothy Porter's Wild Surmise. The unexpected return of the form in the past 10 years perhaps signals nostalgia for story-telling social realism, but this longer format can also highlightweaknesses.

As Laurie Duggan, who won this year's Age poetry Book of the Year prize, writes: "The surrealists escaped from the detention centre of naturalism into the high-security prison of mythography."

Jenkins's eight-line stanzas are composed of roughly 10-syllable lines and end on a rhyming couplet. This stanza is inspired by ottava rima used by Ariosto and Byron. The decorativeness and humour in Jenkins's sparkling whimsical collaborations with Ken Bolton seem less amusing here.

In A Break in the Weather, he creates an easygoing style, but both line length and couplet tend to be overshadowed by relentless internal rhymes that can snag or delay rather than beguile. The romantic impulse, apparent in Jenkins's earlier work, remains in this classic quest story.

Bruce, the orphaned hero, is a sort of Moses figure who must discover new worlds or save this one. He finds love with Japanese Miko holidaying at Uluru, who, along with Bruce's former teacher, Kato, assists in the quest. Meanwhile, Bruce's contemporary, Imre Nero, who inadvertently starts a forest fire, represents polluting industry. Bruce is trying to save the coral reef - these "dynasties of coral lives" - from being bleached by pollution.

This archetypal topical story runs gaily along and Jenkins is amusingly self-referential: "And this is true, / no glib invention of a loony poet who's / Taking you for some cavalier ride, though he / might do that too - but not here, and not today". There's also Bruce's definition of poetry: "problem-solving, in poetry, is a matter more / of aesthetics -/and of this, / novelty is born, and originality / takes wing".

A poem comes out of Bruce like a packet of Twisties from a machine. Such elucidations seem unnecessary, particularly at the end, where Jenkins summarises the moral - "Shall we be wise or foolish?/Or are we simply / labouring in ignorance, spurred on by greed / and fear - First World excess, Third World need?"

A Break in the Weather is an ambitious book, wishing to inform, protest and entertain, but the constraints of even the loose ottava rima result in some tortured or cliched language that even irony can't excuse.

Laurie Duggan takes that flimsiest of topics, oneself, yet manages to conjure the universal - "Who is left, scratching for a narrative / along this river side // under a cathedral ceiling / registering the traffic; // whose face / assembles every day in the mirror". As Duggan says - "the diary shapes the life" and in Mangroves, and much of Duggan's work, the life shapes the era. Duggan's experiences are talismanic, advertisements for the time they describe where "poetry is the original cultural study absorbing all the data a grand sweep obscures".

Mangroves' long sequences illustrates this statement and are filled with playful opinions - "The N.Z. landscape defeated the impressionists / (either its light was wrong or / wind blew the easel over)".

Duggan's diversity has made him difficult to place or assess. His earlier The Epigrams of Martial (1989), his brilliant parodies of enemies and friends, his "cultural study" The Ash Range (1987), all show a chameleon-like ability to propel other voices. Here his translations of Ardengo Soffici (1879-1964) - "Youth, you pass like the end of a movie I walk out on, / lit up by the rolling credits / in a fabulous suit of old manifestoes" - contrast with his own long sequences such as the ever-expanding Blue Hills.

Our imperfect world is an affront to the impassioned yet world-weary Soffici; Duggan on the other hand perpetuates wonder, doubt, atmosphere. Mangroves begins with a Blue Hills sequence and moves to attempts at definitions of art in both the Cultural Studies and Louvres sequences. Art and Music list the writer's tastes chronologically, displaying his armoury, but Duggan's main concern is always poetry - "Is sense made simply/ through binding together/ disjunctives - as though/ fragments of pictures/ will always make a picture/ whatever the source" - questions perhaps answered by some younger poets.

His recollections of the 1970s and 1980s circle his poetic apprenticeship - "I stood outside the poetry reading / waiting for the mushrooms to work" (Darlington 1974). Mangroves turns on eternal questions: "What place poetry in a world of commodities? Is it possible to make a `serious portrait of my times' when the objects I describe will not remain as collateral . . . But even the houses now mock sturdily their progenitors: `colonials' with insulated walls. Should poetry feign continuities like these buildings do?". Mangroves is poetry of reflection and doubt, at a time "where God and Mammon/ are lifestyle choices". Another section has an epigraph from British poet Denise Riley - "one longs to substitute a new practice of `destructive writing' " - in which Duggan ponders the direction and meaning of poetry now, apparently without the old "certainties decades past" that inspire his versatility.

Gig Ryan won the Victorian Premier's Poetry prize for Heroic Money.

Photo: Laurie Duggan's Mangroves turns on eternal questions. PICTURE: ANDY ZAKELI

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NM20-TXN5-S05S-00000-00(VOLCANOES)1994-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWSEnvironment Watch - Earthweek: Diary of a planetPg. 8(VOLCANOES)Nature ReportSteve Newman

VOLCANOES.

Western Mexico's Colima Volcano erupted with a towering cloud of ash and rocks that forced 500 people to flee from ranches around the mountain's flanks. Civil defence officials said the eruption released pent-up gases that had been building for several days.

In the Philippines, torrential rain falling over super-hot deposits on the slopes of Mount Pinatubo produced an explosion that sent ash flying over a wide area. The former US-operated Clark Air Force Base was blanketed with an ankle-deep layer of the volcanic debris.

FLOODS.

The death toll from a week of torrential rainstorms in southern China reached 100, with the worst flooding feared yet to come. Some cities in Guangxi province were in six metres of water, and hundreds of thousands of homes have been destroyed. Almost 600 people have been killed in Guangxi and Guangdong province during the past two months of flooding, brought on by a series of tropical storms.

HIGH HEAT.

A heat wave in southern Morocco has damaged fruit and vegetable crops worth $12 million in the Souss Valley, the Agriculture Minister, Mr Abdelaziz Meziane, told reporters. Unusually high temperatures, soaring to more than 50 degrees, combined with strong desert winds during the first half of July to destroy 3300 hectares of crops.

A bout of heat in Poland is expected to sharply lower grain crop yields across the country. Rains and cooler weather are needed to save much of this summer's harvest, and the winter crop may be at risk if regular rains fail to arrive.

LOCUST INVASIONS.

The spokesman for the international Red Locust Control Organisation warned reporters that agriculture in parts of Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi and Zaire is in imminent danger of invasion by the pest.

Swarms of red locusts recently have begun breeding in western Tanzania, but the Rwandan civil war has kept international aid agencies from dealing with this new regional threat.

Kazakhstan called on its neighboring CIS countries to help combat a mounting invasion of desert locusts.

WILDFIRES.

A forest fire that raged for two days on the Gallipoli peninsula killed a fire chief and charred several war monuments before it could be contained. Heat from the firestorm set off two land mines that were left over from the battle of Gallipoli in World War I.

TROPICAL STORMS.

Hurricane Emilia, the most powerful storm ever to form in the eastern Pacific, sent high surf pounding into the beaches of Hawaii as it passed south of the island chain. In Japan, typhoon Walt brought much- needed rainfall to drought-stricken Shikoku Island. The storm lost much of its force just before making landfall.

Hurricane Gilma travelled a westward path between Mexico and the Hawaiian Islands, then dissipated far from any land areas.

EARTHQUAKES.

New Delhi was rocked by a moderate quake that wrecked some older buildings in the Indian capital and sent panicked residents into the streets.

Earth movements also were felt in central and northern Japan, Sumatra, western Korea, Vanuatu, northern Iran, Panama, Antigua and southern California.

NATURE'S REFUGEES.

The endangered mountain gorillas featured in the film `Gorillas in the Mist' are being threatened by the massive movement of Rwandan civil war refugees passing through their wilderness park home. The Parc Nacionale des Volcans had been spared from the chaos of the past few months because both sides in the conflict agreed to keep the fighting outside of its borders. Exiled park officials in neighboring Zaire say the park is now filling up with a steady stream of Rwandan refugees, carrying mattresses and other belongings. It is likely the gorillas are being driven to higher altitudes where they will be susceptible to a range of respiratory diseases. They may return to find much of their fragile habitat has been destroyed by the human refugees.

* Additional sources: US Climate Analysis Centre, US Earthquake Information Centre and the World Meteorological Organisation.

urn:contentItem:4597-VYP0-0197-D4G4-00000-00<published>1998-06-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Thugs bring shame to England - again</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Bruce Wilson in Paris</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">DEVOTEES Of the Peanuts comic strip will know that, year in and year</p><p nitf:lede="true">out, Lucy offers to hold the football for Charlie Brown, promising</p><p nitf:lede="true">that this time she will not, not, NOT whisk it away at the last</p><p nitf:lede="true">moment.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Every time, though, she does, and every time Charlie Brown falls flat</p><p nitf:lede="true">on his back. If you live, as I do, in England, that is how you feel</p><p nitf:lede="true">about England, soccer and football violence.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Year in and year out the authorities ranging from Government through</p><p nitf:lede="true">Scotland Yard to the Football Association and the clubs tell us</p><p nitf:lede="true">that, this time, there will not, not, NOT be violence by England</p><p nitf:lede="true">supporters, that all the hooligans have been identified, that the most</p><p nitf:lede="true">sophisticated intelligence operation since M ran 007 was under way to</p><p nitf:lede="true">stop it.</p><p>Every time, though, there we all are, flat on our backs again as the</p><p>yobs run riot, as they did yesterday in Marseille until the tough</p><p>French riot police got them under control.</p><p>About the only good thing that should come out of it is that England</p><p>will now almost certainly not get the 2006 World Cup.</p><p>Britain's Sports Minister, a football nut called Tony Banks, called</p><p>the rioters in Marseille "a moronic minority of drunken, brain-dead</p><p>louts", but that excuse just won't wash anymore. Eye-witnesses,</p><p>including British journalists, are adamant that the thugs were as</p><p>well-organised as a military unit.</p><p>Their leaders were heard shouting orders, telling their troops to</p><p>stand firm in the face of French baton charges, a thin red line of</p><p>thuggery. Or, rather, red, white and blue because all these jokers</p><p>will tell you that they are patriots, fighting for England and</p><p>justice.</p><p>In this case, the excuse is that the rotten French failed to make</p><p>enough tickets available. There are reported to be 20,000 British fans</p><p>in and around Marseille, of whom only 9000 have tickets. But that is</p><p>not the issue; the issue is how did the 20,000 get there, find</p><p>somewhere to stay (I'm damned if I could), and carry with them the</p><p>dregs of British soccer hooliganism?</p><p>Already there is the pathetic chant of "we were provoked". This is</p><p>said to have come from the resident Tunisian population of Marseille,</p><p>that does indeed include its percentage of street thugs. But it was</p><p>clear that this was not random violence; once it started, it erupted</p><p>like a planned battle, not a sudden forest fire.</p><p>Some of the English were so drunk they could hardly stand so, even</p><p>though they are disgusting enough, if they could hardly stand, they</p><p>could hardly fight either. No; the real fighters in these guerilla</p><p>wars aren't drunks, but genuine men of violence, hard-eyed and sober.</p><p>And by no means in the first flush of youth. Many are veterans of</p><p>campaigns ranging back 20 years.</p><p>Last year they went to Rome (again ticketless) to fight, and had</p><p>prolonged battles with Italian police. In 1996 during the European Cup</p><p>there was a bloody riot in Trafalgar Square where many of the fighters</p><p>were identified as being members of either far-right political parties</p><p>or anarchists.</p><p>In February, 1995, an England-Ireland match in Dublin was abandoned</p><p>after rioting broke out. The men who started it were all well-known to</p><p>the police, and it has never been satisfactorily answered how they</p><p>were allowed to travel to Dublin.</p><p>In Marseille last night, some of the fighters were identified by</p><p>British police as known football thugs allegedly under court-ordered</p><p>travel restrictions. Yet they made it to southern France, all right.</p><p>Some travel restrictions; some intelligence; some policing.</p><p>Already British newspapers are calling it another "Day of Shame" for</p><p>British sport, and so it was. But how many have we had before? When</p><p>did England last travel abroad when there were no incidents at all?</p><p>One English FA official, Steve Double, admitted yesterday that</p><p>questions already had been raised on whether England should pull out</p><p>of this World Cup and go home. Of course, that won't happen . . . yet.</p><p>Nobody would be brave enough to take such a decision . . . yet.</p><p>Instead, the innocent will be allowed to suffer, like the Frenchwoman</p><p>who stood weeping in the wreckage of her Old Town cafe and bar,</p><p>saying, "They have broken everything. I have nothing left."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49KH-5TH0-01S8-G0D2-00000-00<published>1988-01-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WIND COMES TO THE RESCUE FOR THE LUCKY 200 OF WILMINGTON</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MALE A</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Wind comes to the rescue for the lucky 200 of Wilmington From ANDREW MALE at Wilmington A SUDDEN wind change yesterday saved the northern South Australian town of Wilmington from a massive bushfire. The town's 200 residents were evacuated to the local primary school yesterday afternoon as the fire approached. About 5.30 p.m., with the fire less than 2 km from the town, almost 300 km north of Adelaide, a lull and sudden wind change turned the fire back on itself. At one point the local golf course was ablaze, ignited by ash blown from the fire. At the height of the blaze, visibility within the town was less than 200 m. Police sealed off roads to Wilmington early yesterday afternoon as hundreds of firefighters battled the blaze. The fire, which has burnt in the mid-Flinders for almost a week, swung towards the town after gusty winds blew it across the Flinders Ranges. The fire's western front jumped the Port Pirie-Port Augusta road on the Spencer Gulf side of the ranges before the cool change. The change brought with it gusty south-east winds. After the fire had sprung up again, more than 30 fire units rushed to Wilmington to save the town. Units from surrounding districts, including some which had been fighting major fires in Wilpena Pound to the north, combined to fight the blaze. They formed a barrier at Alligator Gorge Road, less than 2 km south of the town, to fight the fire about 4 p.m. Graders and firemen carved and burnt fire breaks through the surrounding hills.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Wilmington residents were allowed to return to their homes just after 7 p.m. At Wilpena Pound, fire yesterday threatened the Wilpena Tourist Centre for the second time in three days before sweeping into inaccessable country to continue burning out of control overnight. Firemen took over the centre as a command post about 1 p.m. after evacuating staff to a nearby airfield as they were preparing lunch for a party of French and Australian tourists. The fire, fanned by variable winds, raged within 150 m of the resort buildings before burning to the south-east, west and north of Wilpena Pound. Last night fire was burning unchecked in most areas of the pound. About 70 percent of the pound, about 10,000 ha, has been burnt out. In Victoria and Tasmania, cooler temperatures and some rain are forecast today to help weary firefighters who have been battling bushfires for almost a week. Rain brought relief to many areas yesterday. A total fire ban was called off in Tasmania after milder-than-expected weather. A forest fire in the Tasmania's remote south-west Jubilee Range conservation region continued to burn, but the fire was in remote bushland and did not threaten houses. In Victoria, a fire crew headed to East Gippsland after a report of smoke at Mount Hotham in the State's east. Conservation, Forests and Lands Department chief fire officer Mr Barry Johnston said all other Victorian fires were under control or had been checked. In New South Wales, a total fire ban was imposed yesterday on the north-west plains, centred on Moree, as the fire danger soared through much of the State. Bans were imposed on Monday night on the central-west slopes and plains, the south-west slopes, Riverina, upper and lower western. A bushfire operations centre spokesman said there were several minor blazes around the State but none was causing any concern. WENDY RAY and her brother, Michael Jarvis, load household possessions into a trailer as they prepare to leave Wilmington. WILMINGTON firefighters Barry Piltz and Fay Spaeth prepare to battle the fire as thick smoke envelopes the town.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PICS SHOW BARRY PILTZ AND FAY SPAETH, WENDY RAY AND HER BROTHER MICHAEL JARVIS LOADING HOUSEHOLD POSSESSIONS</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P85-13R0-TXN5-R27P-00000-00HEAT AND PRAYERS AS FIRE HERO MOURNED1994-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 19HEAT AND PRAYERS AS FIRE HERO MOURNEDTHE BUSHFIRE BATTLEGREG LENTHEN

A stiff south-westerly thrashed against the small stone church in Sutton Forest, near Moss Vale, as they gathered to farewell volunteer firefighter Mr Bob Page.

The hot wind ruffled the mourners as they filed into the tiny All Saints'Church to honour the Bundanoon Bush Fire Brigade member killed by a falling tree on Tuesday, fighting a forest fire near Grafton.

The Rev Richard Lane revealed to mourners that Mr Page had planned to leave the Grafton area the day before he died. The change of plan had cost his life

"It seems so unfair", Mr Lane continued, "no, it is so unfair", he corrected himself, gesturing to the casket in front of the small carved wooden altar.

Before him sat Mr Page's widow, Rosemary, comforted by their nine children and as many grandchildren.

The back of the cream-painted church was bright orange with the uniforms which marked out the volunteers, grief mingling with weariness on their faces. On one pew sat members of the crew which was with Mr Page when he died.

They had all come together, Mr Lane told the more than 100 mourners in the church and as many again outside, "to honour and respect Bob and to give him the best farewell we could".

The Bush Fire Services Department assistant commissioner of operations, Mr Tony Gates, told the gathering he didn't know Mr Page personally but knew the sort of person he was, adding, "and there are thousands of them in the field today".

He quickly sketched the dead volunteer's life. A boilermaker from Sydney who had turned to the land "to raise cattle, sheep and lots of kids". He'd been in real estate in Berrima from 1988 before coming to Bundanoon barely a year ago and joining the local brigade as an equipment officer.

He would be remembered as "a good mate ... who gave himself to protect others".

At the back of the church, one of Mr Page's crew shook with sobs as Mr Gates concluded: "Bob has not signed off the attendance book - he is still on duty."

The volunteers sought some comfort from a reading of Psalm 121, I Will Lift Mine Eyes Unto The Hills, before joining their gruff baritones in Psalm 23, The Lord Is My Shepherd.

The Rev Steve Davis led a prayer "for those fighting the fires ... for the injured ... and all those suffering heat exhaustion. We pray for a drop in temperature and a drop in the winds. Father, we pray for rain.

"Be with those fighting the fires and bring relief to our land."

The orange uniforms filed out first to form an honour guard.

Mrs Rosemary Page stood outside the 160-year-old church, poised and dignified, accepting condolences from an official party headed by the Minister for Police, Mr Griffiths.

The cortege moved out - and a swirl of dust tore along behind it through the church gates.

BUSH VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS

70,000 volunteers, 5,000 fighting fires

WHAT THEY WEAR: Helmet, light cotton overalls, cotton gloves, leather boots. Water bottle, goggles and face cloth to counter smoke inhalation attached to utility belt. Knapsack water container for fighting spot fires.

HOW LONG THEY WORK: Two crews work in alternating 12-hour shifts. Most volunteers carry sleeping bags and bed down where possible.

WHAT THEY USE: 4WD Fire tankers for their speed and manoeuvrability. Four to five men assigned to each tanker. Tanks hold between 2,000 and 4,500 litres of weater - lasts upp to four or five hours. In emergency can be emptied in three minutes. Chemical foam added to water to increase volume. Fuel and drip torches for backburning.

Illus: Volunteers, who were with Mr Page when he died, give him "the best farewell we could". Right, his coffin is carried out. Pictures by GREG WHITE Port: Mrs Rosemary Page, with Mr Page's firefighter's hat. Table: Bush Volunteer Firefighters - What they wear, How long they work, What they use

urn:contentItem:4PGY-WRH0-TXN5-R0DH-00000-00PRUNING: SHOW NO MERCY1993-10-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisHOME AND GARDENPg. 127PRUNING: SHOW NO MERCYDOWN TO EARTHPamela Jane

THE end of spring is no time to be a wimp with the secateurs - the most bountiful blossom next year is reserved for those who cut boldest.

The spectacular dwarf almond (Prunus glandulosa) which smothers its long stems with beautiful blossom through spring, is an example of how tough you must be. Once the flowers die and leaves appear, the stems must be cut right back to the ground.

Do not be tempted to be merciful. Any stems left will produce only a miserable show of flowers on the year's new top growth. Ornamental peaches and cherries can be cut back after flowering, too, particularly a lovely hybrid called Elvins. Pruning the branches by at least a third will encourage a better display next year.

Among the shrubs, Weigela, Kolkwitzia, Ceanothus, Philadelphus, Kerria, May, Forsythia and deciduous Viburnums will all benefit if old canes growing from the base are cut out to make room for new growth.

You should take a long-term view, too, in pruning shrubs to a shape and size to suit your garden. Old-fashioned rambling roses should be pruned after the spring flush - unlike the hybrid teas and floribundas which are cut back while the stems are bare in winter.

Ramblers include the Banksia rose - thornless and densely packed with pale-yellow or white double flowers and the prickly Wichurianas, like Dorothy Perkins, which flower later. Many miniature roses also need pruning after the first spring flowers.

You need to be careful in cutting old-fashioned shrub roses - some should be pruned after flowering and some should not. Try to check with a nursery which specialises in roses.

Another point about roses is that cutting flowers is a form of pruning. Always pick blooms with long stems and cut just above an outward pointing bud. Dead flowers should be cut off the same way and dropped in a rubbish bin - not in the compost heap or left on the ground |

Many native plants benefit from after-flower pruning in spring. Bottlebrushes, for example, become straggly and unattractive if the old heads are left to form capsules. Snip off the dead flowers a few centimetres down the stem. New leafy growth will emerge quickly from the centre of the dead flower and fresh shoots will develop a week or so later. Next year the whole shrub will be denser and shapelier.

After spring pruning is complete it is wise to water each plant well and feed with some slow-release general purpose fertiliser, or make a mulch of compost and manure (try the new totally organic pulverised sheep manure called Merino Super Lifter)

and lay this around the roots.

VERSATILE NEW FLOWER

FLOWER Carpet White is the name of a new groundcover rose released by Tesselaars and described as disease hardy, fragrant, and easy to grow. It is more compact than the pink form released last year and could be lovely massed in beds, along borders or, with a little fancy pruning, grown as a hedge. It will also suit a hanging basket. Plants can be ordered from nurseries or Tesselaars (03) 737 9305.

TIPPLE TALES TOLD

LEARN how to make liqueurs and associated products with fruit, nuts, berries, flowers, herbs and spices in a workshop by Rhonda Byrne at the Visitors Centre at Sydney's Royal Botanic Garden. It runs from 10am to 3.30pm on Thursday, November 11, and costs $30 plus BYO ingredients. Phone (02) 231 8128 for tickets or information.

The Iris Society is running an exhibition in The Glasshouse at Swane's Nursery, 490 Galston Road, Dural, until November 7. The nursery is taking bookings for Ben Swane's Practical Gardening Seminar on Wednesday, November 15 or Saturday, November 18. Phone (02) 651 1322.

COLOUR YOUR AUTUMN

ANNUAL flower seeds sown now will provide an abundance of colour through until late autumn. Yates offers a wide selection including, Colour Carpet Aster, Fairy Fountains and Forest Fire Celosia, Candy Phlox, Californian poppy, Sonata and Sunnygold Cosmos, African King and Honeycomb marigold, Dazzler and Colour Parade Petunia, Cocktail Portulaca, Dwarf Scarlet Salvia, Bronze Shades Sunflower, Vitality Verbena and Gold Medal Zinnia.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YG50-TXN5-R39N-00000-00WEEK IN REVIEW1987-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 37WEEK IN REVIEWOWEN CRAIG

THE NATION

OPPOSITION Leader John Howard offered voters a radical mix of across-the-board income tax cuts from next February, paid for by a three-year plan to reduce Government spending by 10 per cent. Mr Howard claimed his tax plan will give the average family a tax cut of $26 a week. The Treasurer, Paul Keating, responded by saying: "If people sup from Mr Howard's tax cup, they will be poisoned by it."

The United States Ambassador, Mr Bill Lane, rejected allegations made by a top Reagan Administration official that Foreign Minister Bill Hayden was"anti-American". Replying to remarks made by Mr Richard Perle, the hawkish former US Assistant Secretary of Defence, Mr Lane, said: "Mr Hayden has strongly supported the Australian and American alliance, as have all his predecessors."

Flame safety lamps have been withdrawn at virtually all underground coalmines in Queensland to comply with the official inquiry into the Moura mine disaster in which 12 central Queensland coalminers died last year. The 32-page Mining Warden's report found that a methane gas explosion was probably caused by the flame of a safety lamp.

CSIRO scientists are planning to make Australia the storage place for the world's radioactive waste. The scientists have found a way of establishing a self-contained "loop" of groundwater to cool buried wastes immobilised in Synroc, the material developed by an Australian scientist for storing highly radioactive wastes permanently and safely.

A jury of seven men and four women took 9 1/2 hours and an overnight lock-up to find four men guilty of the abduction, robbing, sexual assault and murder of Anita Cobby after an 11-week trial. The 26-year-old Sydney Hospital nurse was found murdered in a paddock near Sydney in February 1986.

THE WORLD

AFTER storming to victory in the British General Election, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told her supporters: "We have just had the most fantastic triumph, the third term with the same Prime Minister." However, Labour won almost all the seats in Scotland and Wales, and Labour leader Neil Kinnock warned that the country stood in "an even greater abyss of division".

The Venice summit ended with a pledge from the seven leading industrial democracies to step up co-ordination in economic policy, to combat illegal drugs, and to work together to find a cure for the deadly disease AIDS. The summit, attended by President Reagan and leaders from Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy and Japan, also came to a wordy consensus on East-West issues, combating terrorism and ensuring freedom of navigation in the Gulf war zone.

Ms Fawn Hall, Lieutenant-Colonel Oliver North's former secretary, gave damaging testimony against her former boss, with details about smuggled documents, altered memos, and wholesale file shredding. When asked why these things were done, she replied: "It was a policy of mine not to ask questions.

Dr Timoci Bavadra, the deposed Prime Minister of Fiji, asked to see the Queen personally to explain the crisis in his country. The Queen declined his request and Dr Bavadra declined an invitation to see her Secretary, Sir William Heseltine, saying that "the gravity of the crisis" required the personal attention of the Queen as sovereign head of his country.

The spread of China's worst forest fire has been blamed on bureaucratic bungling, and the Minister for Forestry, Mr Yang Zhong, has been sacked for dereliction of duty. Five men have also been arrested for accidentally starting fires in Heilongjiang, and could be executed.

urn:contentItem:4P85-12R0-TXN5-R36Y-00000-00Thai free-fall exposes Indonesia's weaknesses1997-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 9Thai free-fall exposes Indonesia's weaknesses* GATHERING STORM Asia's currency crisisLOUISE WILLIAMS Herald Correspondent in Jakarta

In July, as Thailand was draining its national reserves in an ill-fated attempt to save the baht, the crisis in Bangkok's boardrooms seemed far removed from boom-town Jakarta.

Indonesian and foreign investors perceived significant differences in the economic fundamentals of the two countries and although some flow-on effect was expected as part of declining confidence in South-East Asian currencies, few would have foreseen

the dramatic 50 per cent decline in the rupiah that would follow.

Fundamentally, the Indonesian and Thai economies are different. Indonesia's total debt-to-GNP ratio was 109.5 per cent, considerably lower than Thailand's 197.9 per cent, and its current account deficit per GNP was 3.4 per cent, compared with an alarming 8.9 per cent in Thailand.

On top of that, more than 20 years of steady economic growth of about 7 per cent and careful attention to the advice of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund had created a strong impression that the Soeharto Government had got it right.

But what was perhaps less evident in the murky Indonesian corporate sector was the similarities.

Big Indonesian corporates, facing high domestic interest rates and lulled into a false sense of security by years of exchange-rate controls, were borrowing heavily overseas for ambitious development projects. Like Thailand, the property sector, booming in many of Indonesia's main cities, was seriously exposed on US dollar debts.

When the aftershock of the Thai crisis hit the rupiah, Indonesia's Central Bank refused to make the same mistakes. After spending $1.5 billion propping up the rupiah, it announced that trading bands would be removed, effectively allowing the currency to free-float and let the market set its level. It would not follow Thailand's policy disaster and drain its foreign reserves to try to keep its currency afloat.

Foreign and domestic analysts applauded the Government's pragmatism. Most analysts predicted "some pain" as Indonesia readjusted to a lower rupiah value: its total foreign debts sitting at about $US110 billion ($153 billion), about $US65 billion of which was in private hands.

Short-term debts were estimated at about $US25 billion, considerably less than Thailand's estimated $US45 billion.

A slight downturn in growth was expected and a program of delays and cancellations in infrastructure projects was announced to widespread approval.

The Government dramatically raised interest rates to create a credit squeeze and keep the newly floated rupiah high, the stock market plunged, but economists predicted a slow recovery as interest rates were eased.

But the rupiah just continued to fall. As the currency crisis unravelled, the weaknesses in the Indonesian economy were exposed. Earlier this year, the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd warned of serious problems in the Indonesian banking sector due to an oversupply of banks and too many bad loans.

The World Bank had also warned that the banking sector was weak by international standards, and the economy over-politicised. In particular, it ranked Indonesia poorly for contract enforceability and bureaucratic delays, alluding to the strong links between major developments and the political elite. It also said deregulation was slowing, private debt was increasing rapidly and Indonesia should factor in its sensitivity to global capital flows.

Just how exposed corporate Indonesia is to US dollar debts was becoming clear late last week as business journals published lists of vast debt repayments due. Indocement, for example, which has close links to President Soeharto, is due to repay $US100 million this month.

The dramatic fall in the rupiah on Monday, when 5 per cent was wiped off the currency in morning trading, did not reflect speculative attacks on the rupiah by foreign investors but a buy-up of US dollars by Indonesian companies needing to meet US dollar debt repayments.

Perception, too, seems to be feeding into the gloom surrounding the Indonesian markets. Indonesia is suffering a severe drought and forest fire crisis with crop losses expected. At the same time, it is approaching presidential elections early next year in which President Soeharto is expected to be elected for his last term after more than 30 years in power.

urn:contentItem:6FYS-0VJ3-RV3Y-T0BG-00000-00What was found burning inside a mineshaft near Daylesford?2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:57:25ZLexisNexisWhat was found burning inside a mineshaft near Daylesford?Adam Spencer

Police will investigate Tuesday's incident.

What was found burning inside a mineshaft near Daylesford?

Police will investigate a fire in a mineshaft near Daylesford where suspected domestic rubbish had been thrown inside.

Crews from Forest Fire Management Victoria were called to the scene on Champagne Track in Eganstown, near the Wombat State Forest, just before noon on Tuesday.

It was deemed under control at 4.10pm.

"It is suspected that domestic rubbish had been disposed of in the mineshaft, which was found burning when crews arrived at the scene", a Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action spokesperson said.

"Victoria Police attended and will investigate."

A community information message was issued by Forest Fire Management for smoke in the area.

"There is a fire in a mineshaft on Champagne Track near the Wombat State Forest that has been contained," it said.

"Firefighters will continue to patrol this fire.

"You may see or smell smoke."

- Adam Spencer

urn:contentItem:44K9-GFS0-0197-D4VV-00000-00<published>2000-05-31T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:57:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 50</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>From fizzers and flops to the bizarre</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By STAN JAMES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CHANNEL 9 throws a few movie logs on the fire to keep us warm with The Blazing Forest  (Saturday, 1.30pm, Nine). Unfortunately John Payne can't raise the emotional temperature as a forestry worker more interested in romancing Susan Morrow than chopping wood. Then the big forest fire arrives, which diverts him more than somewhat.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Kevin Whatley is former policeman Jimmy Griffin, working as an insurance investigator in the British TV pilot The Broker's Man: Finding Frank Russell  (9.30pm, Nine).</p><p>His former boss Major Russell appears to be running in a car finance scam and Griffin becomes involved in a complex siege when another of Russell's former colleagues seeks retribution.</p><p> Bad-boy Spanish director Pedro Almodovar's third film, Dark Habits  (9.35pm, SBS), was re-released after many years following his great success with Woman On the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,  in 1988. It's tasteless, often slow but shows the director's bizarre imagination, dynamic and stunning use of color and, especially, his anarchic, offbeat humor. It's about a tiny band of nuns calling themselves the Humble Redeemers, headed by a lesbian mother superior (Julieta Serrano) who is a heroin addict.</p><p> With her faithful followers, Sisters Snake, Manure, Rat and Sin, she faces chaos when a drug-addict nightclub singer (Cristina Pascual) enters their world.</p><p> Following on SBS is Midnight Lovers  (12.25am) an Italian murder trial drama with a twist, starring Claudia Cardinale, Monica Vitti, Vittorio Gassman and Giancarlo Giannini. A woman who is accused of murdering her husband, gives testimony, stirring the sexual fantasies of a frustrated woman juror, who is unaware of the woman's secret relationship with her cold, uncaring husband.</p><p> In the jumbled, slow-moving sequel Highlander II: The Quickening  (2.45am, Nine) the world is protected by a shield wrapped around it by Christopher Lambert, who looks lost.</p><p> Amid contradictions to the first film, the immortals are aliens and even Sean Connery's brief appearance can't lift the proceedings.</p><p> The remake of a 1950s low-budget thriller, Ransom  (Sunday, 8.30pm Seven), is a competent, undistinguished drama, despite director Ron (Apollo 13 ) Howard's efforts to raise the emotional level.</p><p> Mel Gibson (in the role played by Glenn Ford in the original) is millionaire airline owner Tom Mullen, whose son is kidnapped by a gang and held for $2 million ransom. Despite the stereotypical warnings from the gang, Mullen and his wife (Rene Russo in Donna Reed's role) contact the FBI and agree to pay. The handing over of the ransom is botched by lumbering FBI agents. Mullen then has an extraordinary change of heart about paying, which creates turmoil with his wife and the FBI.</p><p> Gibson looks ill at ease and Russo is relegated to gushing responses, creating melodrama instead of nerve-snapping tension.</p><p> Geena Davis is a suburban schoolteacher and amnesia victim Samantha Caine in the classy thriller The Long Kiss Goodnight  (8.30pm, Nine), written by Shane (Lethal Weapon ) Black.</p><p> Married with a young daughter, Samantha can only remember the past eight years and doesn't know how old she is or why she has so many scars on her body.</p><p> It turns out she was an assassin for a secret United States government operation and her old boss wants her dead.</p><p> Davis's then husband and director, Renny Harlin, creates an aesthetic of carnage as Samantha leaps across the screen, accompanied by an astonished private detective (Samuel L. Jackson). She dodges bullets, dispatches men with knives, bullets or neck-snapping in an orgy of explosions, violence, blood, death and doublecross.</p><p> The much troubled (two directors, several rewrites) Fierce Creature  (8.30pm, Ten) loosely links the antics of billionaire New Zealand businessman Rod McCain and his obnoxious son (both played by Kevin Kline), a career-driven marketing expert (Jamie Lee Curtis) and Hong Kong TV manager Rollo Lee (John Cleese).</p><p> Lee is sent to make the zoo extremely profitable by turning it into a zoo with only savage creatures.</p><p> It's met with dismay and horror by an odd collection of keepers led by "Bugsy" Malone (Michael Palin).</p><p> It's wrapped up in a clever and black climax, with plenty of sexual innuendo and crude jokes.</p><p> One of director Ingmar Bergman's finest works, Persona  (10.45pm, SBS), explores the symbiotic relationship between an actress suffering a breakdown (Liv Ullmann) and the nurse caring for her (Bibi Andersson).</p><p> Tailor-made for Charles Bronson fans, Telefon  (11.05pm, Seven) has Bronson as a KGB agent trying to stop an elaborate and highly improbable plot by Stalinists to destroy the US.</p><p> Bronson plays it very cool, which suits Donald Pleasence as a sinister saboteur and Lee Remick as a double agent.</p><p>  *  Star ratings in TV programs</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
